There was a bouquet being gently scolded by a friend for its lack of structural integrity. Rick did his best to be both there and not there, which is a man’s greatest test in rooms where lace is deciding everyone’s posture. Julian was good at handing the right pins and not stepping on the train and finding the humor that did not soil the moment. Cornelius stood and watched the way the mirror arranged the room and the way the room let the mirror lie a little for their benefit, and he felt nothing dramatic; he felt a plain true thing in his chest like he had put down a heavy bag finally and remembered he had hands.

He went outside for air and found Mae on the bench by the tree that had selected itself in Julian’s taxonomy as a good tree. She had a paper bag of pretzels and offered him one exactly the way a friend would in a lunchroom you had accidentally walked into twice. He took it and did not make a thing of the salt stuck to his lip. She said, “I like the window in there. It tells the truth about what light does to a person.”

“It’s a good window,” he said. He thought about asking her if she had left the note on the butter, and then thought about the violence of trying to force a person to match a ghost with your own handwriting. He let the thought wave and go. “You come to weddings,” he said, a sentence that was not an accusation and sounded like one to ears trained to hear the world as trouble. “I mean, to places where people pick what to wear in case it rains and doesn’t.”

“I like fabric stores,” she said. “I like rooms where people collaborate on a future and say ‘Let me think,’ and you can watch them do it. I like alterations. I like the noise of pins in a dish. And I went to buy thread,” she added, producing two spools the exact color of sky an hour after the day ends from a pocket in her sweater that had been mended and remended until it had the texture of a decision you had to make ten times before it stuck. “You looked like a person who would need someone to hand them something if they put their hands in their pockets too long.”

“Thank you,” he said, because that was the word you say when a person has bought thread and memory without reminding you of the price. “Do you know that the plants at my doctor’s office have become photographs.”

“I knew they would,” she said, with the confidence of someone who has seen many things decide to be images. “It is a mercy for both parties. The plant was not fit for the daily rain of certain kinds of sentences. The photograph can take it.”

“Do you leave notes on people’s butter,” he asked, finally, and she laughed, a sound like a lens cap popping.

“I am not your mother,” she said, not unkindly. “I am not your angel. I am not your memory with neat borders. I am a person with a sweater that does not give up. I am a person who knows you know how to fix a light without bullying it, and I like that. That is all.”

He nodded. He could feel the place in his chest where disappointment had tried to prepare a bed. He did not lie down in it. He went back inside and became, again, a person inside a particular day, and that is a job that deserves to be listed when people ask, What do you do.

The night before the wedding there was chicken that had been roasted in a pan older than any of them. There was a salad in a bowl the color of a friendly argument. There were napkins folded with the kind of care that becomes a joke later and then an heirloom. There was a silence after they ate that was not uncomfortable. Rick put his hands on the table and felt the way a different life would have made him a person who drummed on surfaces when he needed attention, and he declined that life in favor of this one, where he could say, “Let me tell you about a day I didn’t know anything and it was fine,” and be believed. Elaine sat in her chair and looked at the men she would call her men and thought about shoes and sorrow and how you arrange them so both behave. Mr. Dwyer washed the chicken pan with tenderness and a minimum of self-congratulation. The light in the downstairs bathroom held. The vent said nothing or said everything and he had stopped needing to decide which it was.

He went to bed and put his hand on the book and thought about the chain and the door and how there is a sweetness in being able to hear a person’s hand on the other side, not knocking, just being. He woke in the night to no smell at all, which was unusual and a gift. He lay and listened to the house do its breathing, the same as his mother had done in the room down the hall, the same as he had done as a child when he swore he could hear his own blood move and had named it a train to make it less lonely. In the morning, there was a single note in the kitchen stuck to the salt cellar with a magnet shaped like the state of Delaware. It read, Keep your windows at half-mast today. There will be weather. I trust you. —M. He laughed a little in his throat because he had expected a list; the note had offered him a sentence and a vote.

The wedding day was a series of small competitions. The weather tried to be both and instead landed on gentleness with a show-off cloud. The vows tried to be original in a town where people had been promising and failing and promising again since sidewalks were chalk. Elaine tried not to cry and then cried anyway and forgave herself with the efficiency of a woman who does not have time to be embarrassed. Rick tried to keep the speech under seven minutes and went to nine, but only one person looked at a watch and that person was Mr. Dwyer because he was timing the moment to tell a story that needed a precise entry point. The photograph that would end up on a mantle had three versions: the one where Cornelius looked like he had accepted something, the one where Julian looked like he had been told a good joke and had tucked it under his tongue to keep, and the one where Tux, who had been smuggled into one group shot as a dare, looked like she owned the house and its social calendar.

There was dancing. Cornelius did his small version of dancing, which is to say he let the music move the area from his elbows to his shoulders and did not attempt anything below the knee that might have suggested he had ideas. Julian did the kind of dancing you do when you have spent enough time in rooms where people forget they have bodies and then remember with relief. He came back to the table flushed and urgent, put a bottle of water down that had been opened by three different cousins in their zeal to help, and said, “I think I got the job,” and Cornelius said, “Water first,” which is how he knew he had started to practice loving a person without making them a project.

The woman who had given them coffee in H-town and said his name had a line at the bar and did not look their way; if he had waved she would have seen him, but the evening had its own logic. Mae stood by the door once, watching, and then left like someone who had a train to catch, whether there was a train or not. Dr. Vale sent a text that read, Do not talk to anyone doing a bit at a reception, which made him laugh and then put his phone away because the phone had no business being at a wedding except to turn into a camera with no future for a second and then leave them alone.

When it was over, when the rice had been replaced by bubbles because someone had read an article, when the candles had been blown with a sigh by a cousin who had questions about fate, when the cake had been less delicious than everyone hoped and better than most cakes, when the shoes had done their work and stumbled off to be forgiven, when the house received them back with its gratefully uncluttered hallway, when Tux yawned at them like a curator closing a museum, when the light in the downstairs bathroom held again because that is who it had decided to be, he went upstairs and took the chain from the door and put it back and took it again and then left it on. He wrote a note that said, Door is on the chain. I am not locking you out; I am inviting you to reach, and he did not sign it, because the point of a signature is sometimes to remind yourself of a name and sometimes to accept that other people remember it for you. He slept and dreamed of bolts that weighed exactly what they should, and woke ready to check if the planes were honest.

In the days after, the house developed a new habit of placing little objects where he could not quite remember leaving them but had to admit he might have: a washer on the edge of the kitchen sink, a ribbon in the bathroom drawer, a button as dark as a joke on the windowsill. He collected them in a small ceramic bowl shaped like a leaf someone had made in a class with a single kiln, because it seemed polite to provide a landing. He wrote no new letters to M and still received one or two, less directive, more companion. One said, You are allowed to be patient without making it an accomplishment. One said, Good. Keep loving the wrong hill; it knows your name. He kept them without feeling like a museum. He told Julian, finally, about the notes; he did it in the car because he trusted that the trees would spin past and eat any excess melodrama. Julian listened and did not ask for proof and did not make a joke and did not make a chart; he put his hand on the gearshift and said, “Okay,” and then a minute later said, “Okay,” again, and that was the exact blessing he had wanted without knowing how to ask for it.

They went back to Laurel Acres and counted in silence, and when he missed a plane, when the bead went missing and did not return to its strand, he felt the old tug and then, like a muscle he had been building without seeing it, he felt the new ease arrive to help. He breathed and did not call it an achievement. He turned his face to the not-quite-right hill and leaned back on his elbows and watched a family try to eat sandwiches on a blanket that had decided it would rather be a cape. The geese gathered anyway in parentheses and scolded the bread for not being allowed. The town moved around them in its jughandle logic. The air smelled like lemon and tomato and the inside of a Wawa and the paper they wrap thread in when they love you a little. He did not practice leaving. He practiced staying, which is the heavier thing and, when done correctly, the good one.Chapter 8

The heat came in like an acquaintance who had promised to call first and didn’t. It tipped its chin at the lawn and the lawn lay down in apology. The hill at Laurel Acres bleached, all the little greens deciding to agree to be one color to make the sky feel less alone. Inside the house, doors swelled as if remembering some old irritation they’d had with being rectangles. Elaine kept the windows at half-mast as if obeying a maritime ritual, which in its own way she was; the house had its flags and she had learned their meanings. The chain on Cornelius’s door began to feel like jewelry on a person who doesn’t think they’re fancy enough to wear it. He touched it in the mornings, making sure the metal remembered how to be a boundary without being punitive. The sash weight in the corner did honest work, reminding the room what down meant. He moved slower, which felt like a luxury and a surrender, and also like something Dr. Vale would call a practice if he brought it to them with a bow.

Julian started the job the way you start a book you were assigned in school and then realize you would have read anyway. He came home with stories about Reggie who had opinions about the right way to eat a hoagie and would fight you with his napkin if you said “sub,” and about Shaila who organized the flow of information with the ferocity of a headmistress that children adore in secret. The database, he said, had been a neglected garden with labels that had given up; he liked weeding, it turned out. He brought home a stress ball the shape of a house given out by some vendor and they took turns squeezing it until it developed the resigned expression of a person who has agreed to be a metaphor. In the mornings they met in the Wawa lot with the sleep still standing behind their ears and traded coffees like keys. On good days, the light was the color of a fresh towel and the planes were already up and practicing. On bad days, the parking lot had the personality of an old bruise and they practiced anyway.

The house conspired to need them. There was a leak in the upstairs bathroom that began as a tiny dark petal in the ceiling over the hallway, the kind of petal you think is a shadow until you look away and come back and it has a border. Cornelius stood under it with his arms crossed because sometimes your posture is part of your toolkit. He remembered the main shutoff because Mr. Dwyer had taught him with the seriousness of a man who had once thought he could fix grief with an adjustable wrench and had found, to his surprise, that water responds better than sorrow does. He went to the basement and found, on the wooden shelf where they kept the things no one can bear to throw away, a folded note. The paper was a torn corner of a paint sample card, the color labeled CLOUD QUILT. The neat handwriting said, Turn the water off at the main while you still want to. —M. It did not sting him, which was either the heat or maturity. He called up to Julian and said, “Trip to the shutoff,” and Julian said, “Aye aye,” because he believed in ritual even when the ritual involved an old valve and a disagreement with a pipe.

They saved the ceiling from becoming a map of a country at war with rivers. The plumber came and affirmed things in a tone that suggested he liked being the authority only because water did not talk back to him in human voices. He praised Cornelius for turning the water off “before the event,” which made Cornelius think of weather and the way it is always happening even when you are ignoring it out of self-care. He did not show the plumber the note. He did not show anyone the note. He put it in his wallet because dissenting from help is a weakness he was trying to starvingly feed until it lost interest.

Mr. Dwyer took the leak as a personal insult and, therefore, an opportunity. He came over with a ladder that had a dent like a memory of a small mistake, and he insisted on climbing it though Elaine made noises like the understudy to a Greek chorus. “I have been up a ladder since Nixon,” he announced. “I know gravity better than she knows me.” He used a patch compound like frosting and then measured the spot with his eye as if it owed him symmetry as back rent. When they were done, he sat at the kitchen table and drank water like medicine and said, “There is a word for the feeling of looking at a ceiling and knowing it is lying. My grandmother had it, but it was in Polish,” and then he stared into his glass and waited to see if the word would migrate to English to spare him effort. It did not.

On a Saturday when the heat pretended to be a necessary personality trait, Mae convinced him to go to the library for a repair café, which is what you call it when people bring their broken toasters and chairs and tougher things and sit in a room full of other people’s skills. The library’s meeting room had that bright institutional sadness that makes certain kinds of hope look more serious. There were card tables with sewing machines and card tables with screwdrivers and card tables with glue guns that had given up on knowing what glue prefers. Mae stood behind a table with screws organized by heads and sizes, and a tray of washers that looked like a coin collection for a country that had refused to be minted properly. “Give me a hinge and I’ll give you a rumor,” she said. “Bring me a latch and I’ll tell you who it was guarding.” He took a chair that had a lilt in one leg and showed it that you could be honest with wood and not be a bully. He liked watching hands solve things. He liked watching faces relax into usefulness.

“Cornelius,” Mae said in the middle of the afternoon, as if she were calling his name to take attendance in a class he had enrolled in by accident. She handed him a small tin with a ship on it. Inside were three antique screws, one with threads that had barely survived their century. Underneath them was a folded paper that had once been a receipt for exactly twelve onions. The neat handwriting said, You are not an emergency. You can leave a thing broken until it tells you it’s ready to return to being a thing. —M. He looked at Mae and she lifted one eyebrow in a movement so small it might have been a stretch. He put the note with his others. He gave the chair back to the lady whose husband stood behind her with a posture that admitted to being the cause, and he let himself feel the enormity of small salvations in a room with fliers about summer reading crinkling with humidity.

Dr. Vale had replaced the photograph of the plant with a living cactus the exact green of a traffic light that is never for you. “A client insisted,” they said when he cocked his head. “They told me I needed a thing that knew how to mind its own water. I agreed. I can only hope it will respect the acoustics.” They wore a linen shirt that had surrendered after the first hour of the day and had settled into honesty. He brought them the notes and they did not pretend to be anything but delighted by the font of his life. “The chain is doing its job,” they said. “It is letting you perform the very human act of both wanting and pausing. Pausing is not refusal; it is courtship. With yourself, yes, but also with anyone who thinks they know you before the second paragraph.”

He told them about Julian’s job and how the apartment in his head where pride lived had suddenly installed proper lighting. He told them about the repair café and the woman with a toaster that had stopped trying because someone had asked it to make bread into a personality. He did not tell them about the ache that lived next to his best feelings like a polite roommate, always brewing tea a little too loudly in the morning. They asked him to notice where in his body he felt it when he believed he was not an emergency. He noticed it in his wrists. He noticed it in his ankles. He noticed that he stopped clenching his teeth when he remembered that pausing is not the same as losing your place.

Elaine, post-wedding, needed a project that wasn’t called “post-wedding.” She tried on the mantle of Relaxed Person and found it hung strange on her shoulders. She cleaned the candleholders until they could have passed the viewing-yourself-in-them test at any department store. She washed curtains. She considered a wall she had always considered paintable and then said, “No,” aloud in a decisive soprano. It was Rick, for once, who suggested they start a supper thing. “People bring food,” he said. “We light the candles, which is your church.” Elaine called it Thursday and refused to give it a name, because names lead to responsibilities and she was experimenting with a week that didn’t scold her. On the first Thursday, six people came, and another one came because they had heard laughter when they walked their dog. Mr. Dwyer brought a salad with fennel and the confidence of a man who believes in his knife. Julian made a pasta that turned out better because he stopped talking to it. Cornelius made beans with lemon and garlic and called it a dinner as if the name conferred adequacy. When they sat down, Elaine said, “Grief sits at this table. That’s fine. We’ll feed it, too.” No one argued. The house recorded the evening in the scrapings of forks like a musician taking notes at a concert.

The planes changed their routes for a week. Somebody somewhere decided the sky needed a haircut. They no longer came in a tidy blackout-drill line from the northeast but sidled in from the west as if embarrassed by their own angles. It ruined counting for a day and then made it better, because counting is not about correctness if you are honest; it is about believing you can distinguish one thing from another and then forgiving yourself when you cannot. Cornelius sat on the wrong hill with Julian and discovered that he could say, “Missed,” without feeling that the sky had done it to punish him. He could say, “There are more beads than I can see,” and mean it as an invitation instead of an apology.

Rick left for a few days to see his father, whose lungs had decided to declare independence. He packed with the theater of a man who never packs but did not overdo it, which is its own victory. He hugged Julian in the doorway with an awkwardness that made them both newly dear to the house. He squeezed Cornelius’s shoulder with a punctuation that did not require decoding. He called from a hospital room with his voice hovering between public and private volume, and Elaine answered with her table voice asked to do hospital duty. The house went quiet in the way a mouth goes quiet when someone reads it a poem. Tux slept in the doorway of the downstairs bathroom with her paws tucked under as if she were holding her own patience. The light held.

On a wet afternoon when steam rose from the street like the town thinking, he sat at the kitchen table alone and put all the notes in a line. They made a line the way flight paths make lines if you draw them long enough. This is me, he thought, with the private comedy he trusted because it did not aim for applause. This is me when I was generous with myself. This is me when I was trying to leave breadcrumbs so good I would pretend to be obligated to follow them. He wrote on a clean index card, because all systems require at least one clean page, I hear you. I am practicing without you for a week. This is not punishment. This is posture. He put the card under the sugar bowl which had always thought it was important anyway. He left it there. He drank his tea unsweet for a day and discovered it was not a moral achievement; it was a taste.

The first night without notes he could feel where the air had been impressed by their absence. He checked his pockets before bed and found only lint and a penny that had seen war. He put his lip to the chain as if he could hear more with the mouth. He slept. He woke and found no paper under his pillow, no napkin under the fruit, no small writing with its neat right angles. He went downstairs and made toast the way a person does when they try to keep their mind from narrating. He checked the fridge. There was only butter and a small civilization of leftovers and a magnet in the shape of Delaware doing its duty. He felt relief without a witness and decided it counted.

He saw Mae in the store, aisle seven, where people come to argue with shower rods. She put a shower caddy in her basket and then took it out and then put it back as if practicing choices. “The notes stop,” she said, not asking and not asserting, and he marveled again at the way some people talk like they are in on a secret you don’t remember telling. He nodded. She looked pleased for him the way a person looks pleased about another person’s haircut even when they know the person will hate it for three days and then grow into their skull. “You will not miss your own handwriting,” she said. “That happens later.” She put the caddy back and left with a pack of hooks and a small bit of string. He could have asked her, then, but he had already decided to respect the week.

On Wednesday, the chain rattled. It was not loud; it was the sound you make with your throat when you consider speaking. He was in his room folding laundry in that precise way that makes shirts forget they are fabric and become a problem to solve. He turned. Tux was in the hall, sitting like a person waiting for an apology. The chain trembled and then lay still. He walked to the door and put his hand against it the way you press your palm to glass at zoos and then hate yourself a little for doing it. He said, “I am here,” because he was. The door said nothing. He opened it and found the hallway unchanged, the carpet doing its unheroic job, the small gouge near the baseboard where someone had once moved a table too optimistically to the left. He closed the door and the chain fell back into place with the comfortable sound of a thing choosing its old job over a new ambition. He put the clean shirts away and let his chest keep discussing it while he ignored them.

On Friday, he did an unforgivable thing. He forgot a bolt. He lifted a small package in aisle ten and believed by the weight that it was fine. He took it to the shelf where it belonged because the old map in his head still listed what belongs where, and three steps later, a feeling like being called by a teacher who had noticed you’d been standing without a reason turned him back. He weighed it again, and it was wrong. Not wrong like grief; wrong like math. He replaced it in the correct place and said, out loud and to himself, “It happens,” and in that moment the week of no notes turned into a habit instead of a dare. He put his hands on the edge of the shelf the way he puts his hands on the table at home, and he did not shoo his heart away when it tried to jump up and prove how helpful it could be.

On Saturday, the sky broke. It used rain like a proof. They drove to the hill anyway because it had become the choreography of their friendship. They sat in the car with the windows fogging in symmetrical ovals like thought bubbles you could never be brave enough to write in. The park filled with people who don’t mind water and ducks who did and geese who have elected not to participate in anyone else’s narrative. Julian reached over without ceremony and adjusted the vent so it would blow on both their hands, and their fingers nearly touched and nearly didn’t. The nose of the car filled with the fleeting smell of something electrical that had not quite committed to failing. “I dreamed last night we were counting trains,” Julian said. “They came upside down and nobody minded.”

“I dreamed your database got tired of being a bouquet and wanted to be a tree,” Cornelius said. “It grew dates like fruit. We had to decide if picking them was murder.”

“Very Catholic of you,” Julian said, startling a laugh out of both of them. He pressed his thumb against the dashboard as if somewhere under there was a button marked Better Weather. “I like the week you gave yourself. I was worried you’d turn it into a creed.”

“I can make a creed out of anything,” Cornelius said. “This week I did not. You’re welcome.”

They went home and someone had left a pie on their front step in a box with a ribbon like an apology in advance. The note on top had been written by a neighbor who calls everyone by their whole name; it said, Congratulations on being the kind of house where mail does not lie. The pie was blueberry, which made Julian make a small delighted noise in a register that belonged to cartoons. They ate it with forks directly from the tin because some Saturdays require the vote of the house and the house had voted for this. Elaine found them and said, “I see you have become pirates,” and took a fork and joined them without lying about wanting a plate. When they were three-quarters done, Cornelius folded the top crust over like a duvet and said, “One more piece,” and then did not take it. The luxury of not finishing a thing felt like being trusted with a small relative.

On the last day of the week, there was a note. It was not in the kitchen or under his pillow or behind the butter which, in summer, had become a person. It was on the stairs window, taped gently with that blue painter’s tape that has never harmed anyone. The handwriting was still neat and still his. It said, Thank you. I did not vanish when you did not call me. You can have me and also have you. —M. He put his nail under the corner of the tape and then lowered his hand because leaving a thing up when you do not absolutely need to take it down is a skill. He leaned his forehead against the glass. The window gave him back the heat of the day softened by evening and whatever you call the temperature of a thought when it has just become less punishing.

He could have told Dr. Vale. He could have told Mae. He could have told Julian the way he had told him about the previous notes, in the car, with the trees obliging their need for a moving confessional. He did not, not immediately. He went instead to the store and held a handful of washers and let them clink into each other like a tiny polite applause. He took the sash weight down into the hall because the air downstairs had taken to shifting when no one turned the fan on, and he wanted to remind the house of consequences gently. He stood at the base of the stairs and thought about the door with the chain and the day with the pie and the way he had said, “It happens,” in the aisle. He stood there until Tux came and sat on his foot, and then he stood another minute because he liked the weight.

At night they lay in the living room again because it had become a position their bodies knew without instruction. The ceiling did its striping trick with the streetlight the way a grandmother does the same card trick every holiday and it is still good. The television showed them a movie where people regret things in airport bars. They turned the sound off at the part where someone said, “You don’t understand,” because they did. Julian said, “I keep thinking about the way your house sounds like it’s about to tell a a joke,” and Cornelius said, “Sometimes it does. Sometimes it only wants to hear if I can laugh.” There was quiet. It was not a test. It was a room where two people had decided to be and were being, with a cat on the back of the couch who would never approve but would always admit to preferring this to a version of the night in which no one was where she could observe them.

The next day, the planes came back to their old line the way a person returns to the route they had known was shorter all along. He and Julian sat on the wrong hill and did the right thing. They counted. They missed. They counted again. Behind them a father told his child an elaborate lie about geese being secret employees of the park whose job was quality control, and Cornelius admired the impulse and the vocabulary and the wrongness. In his pocket, a folded square of blue tape had adhered to the lining as if asking to be taken along in case of sudden note emergencies. He did not write. He did not forbid writing. He watched the small silver wedges announce their intention without asking to be named. He pressed his hand into the grass and felt the old carpet feel of it, cool and matted by other choices. He allowed himself, then, a specific thought that would have embarrassed him a year earlier: there would be more beads. There would be days when he counted them wrong and liked the counting anyway. There would be a chain and a door and a note that said nothing and still spoke. There would be, and he could stay for it.Chapter 9

The storm announced itself with the manners of a guest who texts you from your driveway rather than ringing the bell. The clouds stacked over the highway like furniture you promised you could carry alone. Late afternoon had that sepia bruise you remember from a childhood afternoon when someone told you thunder was angels bowling and you resented the trivialization of noise. The weather app lied in its precise way and then took it back with an update as if admitting it never really meant it. By the time Cornelius left the store, the parking lot had become a reflective surface for other people’s lives and his own, and the men who sell roofing out of vans were blessing themselves with tarps.

At home, the house drew itself small. Elaine went room to room closing windows to the exact half she had been advised to keep them, because ritual offers traction. Rick called twice to say he could see the storm from the expressway as if clouds would behave better if spoken to sternly on speakerphone. Tux took up her position on the fourth stair, the one that had learned to translate vibrations into gossip. Julian came in with the smell of damp denim and the particular brightness you get when you have walked fast through fat drops without bending your head, and they did that thing where they narrated the weather to each other as if the sky craved commentary.

When the power went out, it was the kind of silence that reveals a dozen other noises. The refrigerator’s secrecy became obvious by its lack; the aquarium at the neighbor’s that no one in the house had ever seen but everyone had heard stopped doing its endless river impersonation; the little clock on the microwave forgot its numbers with relief. Somewhere down the block a child cheered as if a goal had been scored. The rain repositioned itself as the main character.

Elaine lit candles because Thursday was over but the table did not know it. Her lighter clicked the way doubts do when they attempt competence. The house accepted the flicker with a grace that suggested it remembered when light was twitchier. “No opening the fridge,” she said, and then opened the fridge to check on the pie and apologized to it with a hand on the door as if to a startled animal. Rick, stranded in Cherry Hill with weather as his alibi, texted an emoji that looked grimly optimistic and then a paragraph about generators that sounded like a warm-hearted threat.

They gathered in the living room because it had the most breathable dark. Outside, the sky cracked open, not the clean line of a break but a rip as if something too large insisted on squeezing through. The streetlight did its own small martyrdom and then nothing. The house exhaled the lemon cleaner smell it had been hoarding in the baseboards since morning and, beneath that, the ordinary scent of their lives: onion bagels, wet socks, tea rings, Mr. Dwyer’s particular cologne which he swore was a soap.

“Do we count the thunder,” Julian asked, sprawled on the floor with his hands behind his head like a person demonstrating that you could live here, in this moment, without convincing anyone.

“You count for distance,” Cornelius said. “I count for company.” He lay beside him, close enough to feel the version of heat that is simply another body being permitted to exist near yours. He could hear Julian breathe and could hear his own breath trying to match and failing, and he let it fail for once without calling it a problem. Tux patrolled the border between them like a lifeguard in an era when swimming was suspicious.

A knock came, the polite kind, like rain had learned table manners. Mae stood on the porch with a lantern of the old-fashioned battery variety and a raincoat whose hood made her look like someone being smuggled into a better story. “I brought these,” she said, handing over two lanterns as if offering time for their use. “And this,” and she produced a roll of blue tape. “For leaving messages you aren’t ready to find.”

“You have a sense of humor,” Julian said, grinning, because he liked discovering other people’s tools.

“I borrow it,” she said. Her hair had found rain in a way that made all other waters seem implausible. She looked past them into the house with the respectful interest of someone entering a gallery. “Your windows are doing their best.”

“We tell them that,” Elaine said, taking the lanterns with thanks that sounded like a little hymn. “You could stay,” she added, as if the offer had been pre-agreed by the walls.

“I would, but my cat does not believe in democracy,” Mae said. “Also, my neighbor thinks this is the best weather for telling you about his knees.” She touched the blue tape to her knuckle and then peeled it away in a gesture that felt ceremonial. “Keep your chain on. Lightning is a door with no respect for invitations.” She disappeared into the rain with the purposeful gait of people who believe in the concept of elsewhere.

They placed the lanterns on the mantle and the floor, and the light they made was the kind that forgives dust. The storm settled into its work: long bellies of thunder rolling tight against each other, white veins of light writing with bad grammar. The house made its corresponding sounds, small sympathetic creaks like affirmations. Cornelius listened for voices the way a person listens for their name in a crowd and heard, for once, none. The quiet felt earned rather than ominous.

Julian read to them from the house book, Chapter Whatever, his voice even and a little amused at the author’s earnestness, and the sentences did useful work, telling them about porches that remember feet and thresholds that document loyalties. Elaine dozed with her mouth just open enough to be human; Tux took this opportunity to inspect her face as if betrayed by its unguardedness. A gust pushed its broad hand against the front door in a way that made the chain identify itself out loud.

When the storm had moved on to flatter places to impress, the house let its muscles go. They didn’t talk about weather the way you talk about people after they leave; they passed around the topic like a bowl and then set it down. The power returned in fits—one attempt that made the refrigerator clear its throat, a second that convinced the hallway light to cough, and finally a steady thrum that made the microwave proud again. The lanterns were turned off with a pat each, the way you treat small animals.

In bed, Cornelius listened to the water complaining in the gutter downspouts and to the small, reliable lie of rain after storm telling you it had always had proportion. He put his hand on the chain as if it were a stethoscope. He did not expect a note after his week without; he expected the feeling of not expecting, which is a complicated thing to hold under your tongue. In the morning there was no paper, only a faint crescent where condensation had dried in the exact place his forehead had rested against the stairs window during some other version of himself. He counted that, too.

In the following days, the town wore its storm habits like a cardigan. Branches arranged themselves into narratives across sidewalks. The man with the dog on Berkley cut the leaves with the seriousness of trimming a bad haircut. On Church Road, the office where Dr. Vale lived had a dark stripe up its stucco belly like a fight it had decided not to win. The cactus in the waiting room looked older as if thunder ages spines. “We survived drama,” Dr. Vale said, tipping their head at the plant. “I am not saying it liked it.”

“I didn’t hate it,” Cornelius said, surprising himself with the admission. He sat and felt the exact rectangle where the lantern had rested on the carpet as if it had imprinted something into his body. “It made me honest. I didn’t miss a bead for a while.” He told them about the lanterns and the blue tape and the lack of voices, about lightning as rude doors and the chain feeling purposeful rather than medicinal.

Dr. Vale stretched in their chair, the vertebrae doing a miniature version of rain on a porch roof. “Absence can be a presence,” they said. “I am told monks have known this for some time. My experience with monks is limited to a bakery, but their advice on bread and sorrow tends to check out.” They pointed their chin gently toward him. “What would it be like if the notes were company and not instructions.”

“I am practicing that,” he said. “I even ate pie from the tin without asking permission.” He told them about the neighbor’s ribbon and the sensation of not finishing on purpose. “I think I’m trying to do everything slower, but not like a virtue. More like a temperature.”

“Rooms have their own climate,” they said. “You’re allowing the house to set you rather than the other way around. I approve. Don’t let it bully you into humidity.”

Work became a minor Eden after the storm in the way that people who move boxes for a living know to be grateful for: the power had not gone out in their section of the strip mall, the backup generator had performed as intended, and the air inside had the blessed consistency of a refrigerator. The bolts were themselves again, proudly standardized in heft. A customer came in looking for a very particular washer and brought with him the smell of a house full of books and a cat. “This one,” Cornelius said after three honest tries, placing in the man’s palm the ring of metal that knew itself. “You can tell because it resists being needed.” The man laughed and said he had never met a washer he didn’t suffer for, and Cornelius experienced the odd pleasure of being someone else’s reliable story by dinnertime.

Julian started to keep a list of things he liked at his new job and taped it to the inside of a kitchen cabinet where no one would see but everyone might feel: the precise way the scanner warms up, Shaila’s whistle when she thinks no one can hear her, the smell of old paper when the humidity changes, the sense that data can forgive if courted properly, the one decrepit ficus near the back exit trying to join the conversation. He showed it to Cornelius over toast and then half-apologized by calling it corny and then took the apology back because some mornings he could see which words were unnecessary and unkind to himself.

Elaine’s Thursday grew in rings like a tree of appetite. The third week, a woman who had not been invited came with carrot salad and an apology that had been through three drafts. She sat and talked about gutters as if the word required accompaniment, and by the end of the night she had told them the kind of story that usually gets a person asked to leave rooms, and no one asked her to. The house takes on tasks when the people inside it let it, and on Thursdays, this house learned how to be a soft place on purpose.

Mr. Dwyer fell off a ladder and did it with enough flourish to make a parable. It was not a high ladder and he had not been warned by cherubs. He had gone up to retrieve a frying pan from the top of his pantry, where he kept things that made him feel secure for their inaccessibility, and the fourth rung had admitted to years. He came down wrong, that plain violent phrase, and sat down in his kitchen like a man who has decided to try sitting in other parts of the house for variety. He called no one because he had been born in an era that taught men wounds were personal curiosities. He walked over two hours later, his pride unrumpled, and stood in the doorway with a forearm he insisted was “only dramatic.”

Elaine sent him to urgent care with a tone that could make butter set. He returned with a sling and instructions to overthink nothing and ibuprofen in a bottle that looked like a small, cheerless building. He accepted both like knighthoods. Cornelius fixed the frying pan handle because some acts of care are better expressed in torque. “I don’t like the sensation of being advised,” Mr. Dwyer confessed, rotating his shoulder as if the words could oil it. “It’s not your fault. It’s the age.”

“Advice isn’t a verdict,” Cornelius said, and Mr. Dwyer made a face that suggested this sentence fit in his wallet.

Mae began to exist in the corners of his week the way a refrain realizes it’s a chorus. He saw her at the library one evening when he went to return the house book because someone else should be allowed to be told that windows get tired. She stood with a teenage boy, demonstrating how to reattach the cover to a paperback with cloth tape and love. The boy pretended not to care and then cared. She saw Cornelius and raised her hand like a pledge in reverse. They exchanged nothing that looked like confession. Later, he found a blue-taped square on the outside of the library’s automatic door with neat handwriting: Doors that open themselves also deserve thanks. —M. He did not peel it up. The thought of strangers walking in and being made more polite warmed a part of him that had been cold since he was eight, when he first understood that public kindness was both rare and contagious.

On a bright and unambitious Sunday, the planes were aggressive with their punctuality. They made their line like an arpeggio you are proud to know by name. He and Julian sat on the wrong hill with the right reactions. Teenagers slid down the grass on flattened boxes because youth is a series of experiments in friction. A small girl in a yellow dress described the sky to a patient aunt as if auditioning to be weather. “You count,” Julian said between sips of the coffee that now had his mouth belonging to a particular morning. “I’ll conduct.”

Cornelius counted. He let himself get lost twice and then found himself once and considered the math fair. He said the numbers out loud because the numbers liked it. When he reached one and nothing arrived, the old sensation of the bead skipping its turn rose and then, like someone careful on stairs, lowered itself. He breathed for two counts longer than felt intuitive and the next plane presented its silver intention and he nodded to it as to a neighbor with good fences.

“I saw your list,” he said to Julian. “In the cabinet. I think you are allowed to like things without hiding them in cupboards. For next time.” He did not blush or apologize; it was a sentence you could inhabit standing up.

Julian turned his head, his mouth doing that half-considering thing that reminded Cornelius of gentle hinges. “I’m trained to believe that liking things gets you mocked. It is a school event.”

“Choose different students,” Cornelius said. “Invite yourself to a nicer lunch table.”

They did not hold hands. They did not need to prove anything to a hill. A breeze found the exact spot where Cornelius’s shirt didn’t meet his skin and made the kind of suggestion you agree to. He turned his face into it and thought of the chain as jewelry again, and the sash weight in the corner of his room reciting its single poem, and the blue tape folded in his wallet in case of emergency gratitude.

The store needed him because a man had bought the wrong anchors and blamed the wall. The man had a vein in his forehead like an underlined word. He said the word “quality” like it owed him back rent. Cornelius thought of posting a sign in the aisle: It is not a sin to change plans. He took the man to the proper package and exchanged nothing but competence. After the man left, Dina from returns said, “You’re good at making people less embarrassing,” and he accepted the praise into his ledger under the category Useful.

In the evening, he and Elaine rebuilt a drawer. It had lived a hard life with the previous family, whose child had been an early years drummer. The bottom had shrugged under the weight of T-shirts and worry. They bought new bottom, as Mr. Dwyer insisted on saying, and slid it into place with a relief that made the room exhale. Elaine told him, over the discovery of a long-lost sock that predated the house, that she dreamed lately of trains and of everyone they had ever been standing on a platform politely waiting for the correct self to arrive. “We were all wearing similar coats,” she said, smiling as if at a bad chorus line that had tried bravely. “I like that. It means if I get the wrong one, it will still keep me warm.”

He found a note that night not in his room or the kitchen or the civilized interior of his wallet but in the car, under the passenger seat, where it had collected crumbs and a small square of sun. The neat handwriting had withstood ash and grit. It read, You can let yourself be touched by what you like without giving it your keys. —M. He folded it, toasted by heat and car, and slid it into the crack behind the radio as if returning it to the God of Dashboard.

On Tuesday, he forgot again. Not a bolt this time, but an hour. He looked at the clock and it stood at a precise time he had lived a hundred times and then it didn’t, and the next thing he knew, he was rinsing tea mugs with the practiced circular motion his body employs when alone. He checked his phone: no calls made, no messages sent, no orders placed. He checked his pockets: one washer, a receipt with onions—always onions—priced at a number that made him laugh, and a blue tape square with a corner folded as if indicating a book he would revisit. He did not panic. He sat on the bottom stair and let the house speak in its harmless bones. He did a thing he had seen children do when they realize they have not been paying attention in class: he wrote by hand the words Here and Now on his palm and did not mind if anyone saw. Julian came in, saw, grinned, and wrote Here and Later on his own hand, lower down, just above where your life line is rumored to make deals.

“Okay,” Julian said, sitting with him so their knees thought about each other politely. “Tell me one small thing, and then two, that anchored in that hour.”

“Steam on the sink,” Cornelius said immediately, grateful for the game as if it were fruit. “The way the towel decided to be a river. A plane turned too slowly,” he added, closing his eyes to see it better, “and became something else and then back, like acting.”

“That’s three,” Julian said. “Overachiever. See? You were alive.”

They went to the Wawa and did not make it an event. The parking lot had the mood of a Monday even though it was not. A man in a suit practiced sincerity on a phone near the air pump. The woman at the register had on glitter eyeliner like apology for the concept of convenience stores at the hour when people lose their stamina. They bought two apples and two coffees and a bag of pretzels pretending to be crafted. On the way out, someone behind them said “Mae?” in the now familiar register, a dim hall calling, but the person who turned was wearing a shirt that said STANFORD with all the letters intact and had a ponytail that apologized for nothing. He could feel the part of him that might have turned anyway growing used to the petting of that voice. He let it go. He could let many things go and not become less.

His mother, post-wedding, post-Thursday, began to take naps. She did it with shame first, and then with competence, and finally with pride. She lay on the couch and threw an arm over her face in the universal posture of brave surrender, and the house played the soft opera of plates settling so she would not feel unaccompanied. Rick attempted the learning of naps and failed, his naps becoming meetings with himself that overshot their agenda. “I will get there,” he told the cat, who had never tried a thing she did not already know she was good at.

There was a Sunday—they were accruing, he was saving them—when the hill received them with particular hospitality. The grass had recovered its plurality of greens. The planes made their music without needing to be named, and the toddlers were excellent ships. They lay back and watched the tops of trees move like gossip among old friends. “Tell me,” Julian said, “something you could never have said a year ago.”

“I like not knowing,” Cornelius said, and each word embarrassed him separately and then they did their teamwork and embarrassed him less. He put his hands behind his head because honesty is treated better by the body in that position. “Everything was neat when I was frightened. Now some things are in piles.”

“I like your piles,” Julian said. “They’re tidy enough to prove you mean it.”

They did not kiss. They did exercise their right to stay in the exact emotional place they had sailed to with their own arms. It was not laziness. It was seamanship. In the parking lot, on their way to the car, Cornelius stopped short and pointed at a plane that wasn’t one: a small kite in the shape of a stingray moving with insolent agreement with the sky. “I want that,” he said, which was either a sentence about toys or the kind of declaration you make eight months into practicing wanting things that might be allowed to happen.

They bought a kite. The day had made room for it. The string trembled in his fingers in a way that made him think of old jewelry. He let the wind tell it who it was. He looked, only once, down at the ground to make sure the hill did not resent him for preferring the air for a second, and the hill looked amused at his need for approval and told him to go on. The kite rode the seam between performance and flight and he did not correct it. Julian held the string when asked and did not let it go even when his hands stung in that clean way you remember when your skin has begged not to be useless. They brought it down in the slow deliberate motion that belongs to both surgeons and bakers and men who are allowed to keep pleasure for later.

That night, he found on the stairs window a smear where a finger had written and wiped and written again. It caught him because the evening had turned the glass into a chalkboard. He touched the spot and felt the cooled outline of a vowel. He breathed on the glass and the word arrived, a negative, a ghost of graphite: Stay. It was not signed. It did not need to be. He laughed, not loudly, just enough to make his ribs say, Yes, this. He put no blue tape around it. He did not show anyone immediately. In the morning it was gone, and he liked that the house had a broom for such things, and that whoever had written it believed he was the kind of person who would obey without keeping evidence pinned under glass.

In the small, serious hours when the store was closed and the refrigerator woke up to complain in the way of appliances whose owners had spoken to them rudely, he woke with a feeling as precise as a phone alarm. He lay there and let it ring. He did not get up. He did not go find paper. He put his hand out into the dark until he found the sash weight, hung where it belonged now, a dark sentence at the corner of the room. He closed his fingers around it briefly, and felt the correctness of the cold, and heard, somewhere inside himself where cheap metaphors go to die and good ones resurrect, the smooth click of something seating into threads exactly made for it. He slept after that with the basic gratitude of a person who can tell the difference between heavy and bad and has proof in his palm and the wrong hill outside doing its right job whether anyone thanked it or not.

Cornelius liked to sit on the hill at Laurel Acres Park and count the planes moving across the dusk. They made a gentle, stuttering line toward the northeast, a strand of slow beads pulled by a quiet string. The geese gathered like parentheses by the water. The park had the smell he always connected with Mount Laurel after rain—wet pavement and red clay, the faint sugar of decaying leaves even in spring, a ribbon of car exhaust from Church Street. And the benches had a complaint to them when you sat down, the boards making a noise he could feel in his teeth. He took off his shoes because the grass felt like the old carpeting in his grandmother’s hallway, flat and cool and slightly matted where people always walked.

He was not alone, though he had trained himself to look that way—chin down, hoodie up, quiet. He carried the ghost of a grocery list in one pocket and the parking lot grit of Wawa in the cuffs of his jeans. He had the awkward hands of someone who had worked in the same big-box store for more years than made sense and could close his eyes and count out twenty bolts by weight. He turned his phone over and over, watched the screen glow, then blacken. He liked the feeling of predicting when the next plane would appear before it did, counting down from five in his head and then seeing that small silver wedge. Only when he reached one with nothing in the sky did he let himself shift, let himself breathe deeper. The world was a test; he wanted a high score.

“Corny,” someone called, and the name slid down the hill like a marble.

He looked up. The wind pressed the hood to the shape of his head for a second, and in that moment he recognized the outline of a person he had met exactly once in a parking lot off Route 38. Yellow hoodie, hair too long for a job interview, that fragile balance between handsome and tired. Julian. He stopped at the top of the hill, weighed something in the glassy eyes that looked like his father’s, then put his hands in his pockets and came down with a careful side-step that said: I fall if I go straight, so I do this instead.

“You’re not supposed to call me that,” Cornelius said, smiling anyway.

“It’s in the brochure. Mount Laurel, the hill park, Wawa coffee, calling you Corny to see you wince. You’re like a local delicacy.”

“Did you just get here?”

“Or we always lived here and didn’t notice before, I can’t decide.”

His hands were clean. That was the first thing Cornelius always noticed about people, which made no sense. He worked around little bags of hardware and plastic wrap and sharpies and packing tape. Marks were normal. Julian’s nails were clean, the palms unscuffed. It meant something. Or nothing at all.

“Mom told me you’d be here,” Julian said, and the word made a shape in the air—Mom—that didn’t fit right yet. His mother, Elaine, had laughed while stirring pasta earlier, one hand on the phone, one at the pot. “He goes there whenever he wants to think. He says he’s not thinking, but you can tell.”

It still felt strange, the future tense of family. Elaine was engaged to Rick, who had a son, who had a voice that was warm like toast. Cornelius had spent the afternoon pushing a flatbed cart of lamps down an aisle beneath lights that hummed like a beehive and thinking: Step-brother is a word people use in jokes. Step-brother is a job I don’t know how to do. And here was the person who would make the word real.

Julian dropped down beside him on the hill. They sat like two pegs in a board, not touching and not talking for a time that could have been five minutes or fifteen; Cornelius always lost sense of time at Laurel Acres. The lake made the sound of slow conversation. Across the way, a child threw bread at the geese and the geese did not care for it.

“How was work?” Julian asked.

“The bolts were weighing less than they should.” Cornelius grinned because he knew it sounded like a complaint from someone’s great-uncle. “New supplier. You can tell if you hold them in two hands. The little ones, not the lag bolts. They’re cheap.”

“That’s a thing you can tell. Good to have a hobby.”

“It’s not a hobby. It’s a talent.”

“Right, sorry. Your supernatural gift.”

“Don’t make fun of me. It’s suburban telekinesis.”

“And useful,” Julian said. “You’re a quality control superhero. QC-Man. The cape has a measuring tape hem.”

He shouldn’t have liked the conversation, and he did. He shouldn’t have liked the way the sunset assembled itself in the little crease at the corner of Julian’s mouth or the way he kept tapping his knee as if counting something out that he was embarrassed to admit. He’d made a habit of not wanting people he had to be around. He was good at that. And yet he remembered how they had met in the Wawa parking lot, how Julian had offered him a sip of hazelnut milkshake blended with actual coffee while their parents went inside to look at wedding magazines and found the birthday card section anyway, which was always how that went. They had stood by the recycling bin and watched a giant pickup try, fail, try, succeed to back into a spot. Julian had said, “I flinch for other people,” and then the straw had been pressed toward Cornelius’s mouth in a way that was not aggressive but also not tentative. This, he discovered, was one of the qualities he recognized in people he would have to leave: knowing exactly where to put things in other people’s space and pretending they were unsure.

“Elaine told me you like to cook,” Julian said now. “She said you once made pancakes in the shapes of states.”

“I don’t like to cook. I like to pretend I know things.”

“So you know what, Maine? Michigan? People always try to do Texas because it’s big, but the bottom part is tricky.”

“I won’t be tested on it,” he said, and then: “Sorry.”

“It’s okay.”

He wanted to ask if Julian called Rick “Dad,” and then he realized there was no way to do that without sounding accusatory. He wanted to ask about Philadelphia, where Julian had been living up until last month, what made him decide to come back across the bridge at an age when most people were trying to go the other way. He wanted to ask if he believed he could start over, because Cornelius didn’t, not really, except in increments so small you could mistake them for error margins. He didn’t ask any of it. He watched a plane descend and meant to follow it to the ground but got distracted by a toddler in a dragon hoodie. When he looked back, the plane had vanished. A bead had gone missing. He felt suddenly anxious, as if he had misplaced an earring.

“I forgot to bring the thing,” Julian said abruptly, as if they had had a whole conversation about a thing. “I was gonna bring that book I told you about. About the guy who does repairs but also he reads buildings like people read tarot cards? The author’s from here. Or Cherry Hill. That counts.”

“I can read bolts,” Cornelius said. “It’s the same thing.”

“Then you’ll like it. I’ll leave it at your—” He caught himself, looked at the river of cars on the road beyond the park. “At Elaine’s.”

Cornelius almost corrected him. It isn’t just Elaine’s anymore; it’s a shared house with a wall that squeaks when you lean on it and a hall light that goes out at inconvenient times and the smell of lemon cleaner even in the places you can’t see. One of the funny things about a house is how it develops a social life after midnight: it shifts and knocks and breathes and calls your name in the heating vents. His room at the top of the stairs had started to say “Corn”—just the first half, like the first tug on a sleeve.

He squinted at the lake. A couple in matching windbreakers argued in a soft way near the edge of the path. A boy’s voice came from behind him and called, “Mae, where’d you put my phone?” and a woman replied, “On the bench, baby,” and when Cornelius turned to look he found no one there, only the top of the hill and the wind compressing the grass into a single stripe. He did not find this strange, but then he often had a radio quality in his head—people tuning in and out. He’d assumed it was the kind of noise everyone had, like when you hear your name in a conversation you weren’t part of. He shook it. The distant girl who called herself Mae laughed again, higher, and then she was gone.

“Do you remember,” he asked without thinking, “the last time you fell in love?”

Julian glanced at him sideways and then pretended a plane was very interesting. “Not a great opening question.”

“It’s not an opening. We’ve met.”

“You act like I’m a book you checked out and got a fine for. Yeah,” he said, after a small pause that had the weight of months in it. He nodded. “I do.”

“And how did you know?”

“I didn’t. Not the way they tell you. It wasn’t like bells. It was like waking up on the wrong couch and smelling oranges and then realizing you’re wearing someone else’s socks.”

“That sounds like bells to me.”

“I’ll show you the socks,” Julian said, and then laughed. “No, don’t look like that. It’s not dirty.”

He was careful enough to say “love” as a topic but not as an arrow, so Cornelius’s skin did not prick all over. He liked that. He liked the way Julian sat with his knees turned in slightly, his feet pressed to the ground as if the earth might, at any second, discard him.

They left before the park lights blinked on. Julian was not from Mount Laurel, not the way Cornelius was, but he had that built-in county geography all the same: he could navigate the chopped-up roads and the old joints and the way a U-turn here put you into a jughandle you didn’t plan to take. They walked past a teenage couple crawling over each other on the hill and then past a man in a bright neon vest throwing a Frisbee to a dog that was clearly in retirement from Frisbee. Cornelius felt everything. He felt the pinch of his socks between his toes. He felt the coin in his pocket press a perfect circle against his thigh. He felt the muscles at the back of his neck tighten and then relax because a sound he could not identify had resolved into a train. He wanted, with blunt suddenness, to tell Julian that he was tired—tired of small newnesses, tired of being in transitional spaces, tired of being watched by things that had no eyes.

At the parking lot, Julian took out his keys and fumbled them, catching them by their lanyard. “I’m staying tonight at the house,” he said. “Rick’s got a meeting early. And the cat’s been ignoring me. I need to win Tux back.”

“Tux doesn’t ignore. Tux judges.” Tux was a tuxedo cat with a formal walk and an unamused mouth. She had arrived with Elaine’s friend Mr. Dwyer and never left. Sometimes Mr. Dwyer still called to ask how “my daughter” was doing, as if he had mislaid her in a grocery store. He showed up with casserole and advice about weather-proofing bathtubs. He installed one towel rack and then wrote a note in Sharpie on the inside of the cabinet door to remind them not to hang wet things on it.

“You like my dad?” Julian asked as they reached his car.

“He’s fine. He is. He has a way of being in a room.”

“He doesn’t mean to do the…you know.” He lifted a shoulder. “He doesn’t know how to sit in quiet places. Or he thinks the quiet will tell him something about him he doesn’t want to hear.”

“We’re going to be family,” Cornelius said, trying out the muscles around the word. “There are worse things than someone who means well.”

“Yeah?”

“Like someone who knows better,” Cornelius said. “But would rather not.”

He found himself making boxes in his head and fitting pieces into them: Julian’s laugh, the way he did not always look at you. The way he stood half-turned. The freckles that had escaped a plan. He put these into the box labeled Dangerous, which in his internal taxonomy often overlapped with the box labeled Fine.

At home the house smelled like lemon cleaner and tomato sauce and a thread of shampoo that had got itself lost downstairs. Elaine stood by the stove, banging a wooden spoon against a jar as if it were a bell in a church no one attended anymore. Rick’s suit jacket hung over the back of a chair, empty of him. The corner of the table had a new chip. Tux walked past them like a rumor and leapt onto the counter. From the living room came the low voice of a newscaster saying a thing that made no impact and then a commercial for a regional jewelry store that had always advertised in this region and always would. Mr. Dwyer, who had a key and a habit of being there, sat on the couch with his legs crossed and a crossword in his lap. He did not look up, but he said, “Four-letter word for your mother’s firstborn.”

“Me,” Cornelius said, walking past and feeling, as he always did, that he was stepping into a photograph he had already seen. He put his hand on Elaine’s shoulder. She leaned into it like a plant.

“I meant ‘Eldest,’” Mr. Dwyer muttered. “Not that it would fit. Whose idea was this grid?”

“Hi, Rick,” Julian called as their father—his father—came down the stairs. They didn’t look alike. Rick had the florid complexion of a person who liked to tell stories into the chest cavity of a beer bottle. He crowded a room. He had a laughter that made you feel praised. He had a habit of making every day into the day before a big game.

“Boys,” he said, and his voice filled the kitchen. He kissed Elaine on the mouth, then drew back and wiped his own mouth with a napkin because of the sauce, then gave her a look that said: I know you hate when I do that. “New lamp came today, Cornelius. We’ll fix that flicker.”

Cornelius found himself nodding, as if the flicker were a person he had promised to meet. He had been the unofficial maintenance person in the house since he was seventeen and the sink had first made a noise like someone drinking too loudly. He was twenty-nine now. It was hard to remember a time before the sink had opinions.

“Go wash your hands,” Elaine said. “I learned last week that apparently grease can come out of towels with club soda. Who knew?”

Mr. Dwyer raised his pencil. “My mother.”

“You haven’t got your mother,” Elaine said. “And neither do I.”

“No one knows club soda this way,” Mr. Dwyer said, and then he looked at Cornelius for the first time. His eyes did this thing sometimes where they didn’t focus correctly but still expressed warmth. He blinked, slow. “You’re late.”

“It’s not dinner if you’re not yelling at me for time,” Cornelius said, and Mr. Dwyer’s mouth softened, as if he were pleased to be part of a pattern.

They ate. They always ate with a formality that surprised people who came to the house for the first time. Elaine lit candles. Even when there was spaghetti. Even when there were just grilled cheese sandwiches. It was her cathedral, the table, and she cleaned the candleholders once a week as if devils lived in wax. Cornelius could tell you which fork was his by feel. Rick told a story about a client who had not known how to say the word “escrow” and would never learn it. Mr. Dwyer complained that his crossword had doubled in difficulty over the last six months; either that or his brain had halved. Julian contributed a remark about a busker on 13th Street whose horse was a unicycle, then got embarrassed, and then leaned over to scoop sauce onto his plate. The unicycle’s horse was all Cornelius could picture now. He saw it in the reflection in the microwave door. He didn’t know if he was present or absent from his life at any given moment. On his good days he could fake it. On his bad days you could see the absence around him like a halo.

Elaine said, “Cornelius is thinking,” and Mr. Dwyer put his pencil down and said, “That boy needs a patent.” Rick said, “No, he needs a vacation,” and Julian said, “No, he needs a—” then stopped, as if he had reached the end of his sentence as a cliff.

“Don’t finish,” Cornelius said. “Let me guess later and be wrong.”

“You could be right,” Julian said. “Isn’t that the point of guessing?”

Cornelius finished eating and washed his plate, because if he didn’t rinse it and stack it the way he liked, the plate would dry sauce in a James Pollock design that would never scrub away without noise. He stacked. He wiped. He let the kitchen light make a hum in his eardrum. He listened for Elaine and Rick arguing in their bedroom—the normal kind, the sort that did not require him to walk to his car at eleven and pretend the radio could save him. No. Tonight, the house was mild-tempered. The lemon cleanser hovered without reproach. Tux sat on the back of the couch and made shapes with her tail like italic letters.

In his room, Cornelius found a paperback on his pillow. The cover had a cutaway drawing of a house, the inside walls exposed, as if someone had peeled it like an orange. A note sat on top of the book, scribbled in blue ink. Look at Chapter 3. It’s the thing about windows. —J.
The J looked like it had been started and then gotten interrupted halfway through. The letter had two attempts at a tail.

He sat on the edge of the bed. The bed squeaked in a way that made his stomach compress. He pressed his palm into the duvet to make it stop. He opened the book. Chapter 3 had a little rust mark from a paperclip someone had lost, but no paperclip. The first sentence read, Some houses wear faces they found in other neighborhoods. He smiled. He wanted to hold the sentence in both hands the way Julian had held the keys. He closed the book and put it on his nightstand and told himself not to read more. He went to the window and looked out. He could count three porch lights on the street, two from houses that had existed long enough to get nicknames on the walking routes and one from the new unit at the end where the family had a subscription to a produce service and it came on Tuesdays.

His phone lit. A message from a contact saved as D. Vale. Tomorrow at 10 still good? I have the room with the plant. The plant may or may not be alive. 
He wrote back: Yes. I’ll bring a plant funeral kit.
He meant to write a follow-up, something about the book, something about being uncomfortable that the plant made him think of himself, but he did not. He put the phone on the bed and then fell asleep with his clothes on and woke an hour later very certain he had had a conversation he could not remember. He looked at his phone to make sure he had not texted anyone a confession or a recipe. The phone did not tell on him. He went back to sleep, and when he woke next he had lines from Chapter 3 in his head as if he had eaten them with his pasta.

The drive to the office on Church Road took fifteen minutes the next morning. It should have taken seven. He counted the lights to time his breathing and then forgot how many there were. He parked behind a building that had once been a house and was now other things. Inside, the hall smelled like carpet and paper. No music. No receptionist, because D. Vale didn’t believe in them. A waiting room that did not want to be one. A plant that did not want to be alive. He pressed his thumb to a crease in the armrest of a chair and it came away with dust in it.

“Cornelius,” Dr. Vale said, coming from the back. They held a mug and had a face that suggested they never got enough sleep because they were eavesdropping on the neighbors’ dreams. They had a way of making you feel that your name was someone else’s name and you were using it while the other person was at lunch. He stood. They made a small show of looking at the plant. “You win. It’s dead. No amount of water changes what is essentially a succulent’s headstone.”

“I forgot the funeral kit,” he said, smiling because he wanted to.

“You brought yourself. Good enough for my purposes.”

The room had one window. The window had a blind that worked only when you pressed it exactly in the place where someone had before. He sat in the chair with the notch that fit his shoulder blade. Dr. Vale sat across and threw their leg over their knee and let their shoulders slouch in a way that made him condition his own to respond. He thought of the word “splay,” and then he thought of the word “sprawl,” and then he realized he was rearranging the letters to make a new person. He stopped. He did not like to be caught rearranging.

“How are you?” Dr. Vale asked.

“I counted planes.”

“Any crashes?”

“Don’t do that,” he said, quietly.

“Sorry. My mouth moves before my good judgment. Tell me.”

“I met him at the park,” he said, and when Dr. Vale tilted their head he added, “Julian. Rick’s son.”

“How was it?”

“Like a paper cup. Smooth and cheap and a little soft.”

“I can work with that metaphor,” they said, and wrote nothing down. He’d never seen them write anything down. He didn’t know if they remembered or if the point was to make a life that did not require notes.

“He was kind. He asked questions. He didn’t try to win. He had a story about unicycles,” Cornelius said, and heard a small laugh come out of his own throat because the absurdity made a shape in the room that was better than the plant. “He brought me a book.”

“I like him,” Dr. Vale said, as if they had already been there with him.

“You like that I like him.”

“I like that you like anyone,” they said. “Are you telling him?”

“About liking?” He felt a needle prick inside. He found himself looking at the window, calculating if someone outside could see his mouth. “No.”

“About any of it.”

This was their shorthand. This could mean different things on different days. Today it meant: Are you telling him about why the ends of your sentences sometimes come with static? Are you telling him about the way you lose pieces of your week? Are you telling him about the names you find in your pockets that you don’t recognize in your handwriting? It also meant: Are you telling him you were in love with a person once who never heard you say it?

“I don’t know enough to tell anything,” he said.

They nodded. “Is it like the book? Can you read him like bolts?”

“He’s heavy enough,” Cornelius said. He pressed his thumb to the chair’s notch. He thought of the “someone else” in the note on his pillow. Not someone else; that had been in his head. He thought of the way the geese had refused bread. “There’s a singer. He mentioned a singer in Philly, or a band, and I thought that he…I don’t know. It was nothing. I have thoughts that are just air for a living.”

“What about Mae?” they asked, casually.

He blinked. The name dropped like a penny into a fountain, made a delicate plop. “Mae?”

“You mentioned her last week. The person at the coffee place who knows to put extra sugar in your tea.”

“Oh,” Cornelius said, with the relief of someone who had misplaced their wallet and then found it in their other coat. “She’s nice.”

“And Mr. Dwyer?”

“He was doing a crossword on our couch.” He felt, for a second, a tug at the back of his head, as if someone was pulling a string out of his scalp. He pressed his palm flat. “He asked for a four-letter word for firstborn.”

“And your father?”

He made a face. “He walked into the kitchen and made a mess of the way the light works.”

“Tell me one small thing that is not about someone else,” they said. It had the air of an assignment. He looked at his hands. He looked at the plant. He looked at the cup in Dr. Vale’s hand and the line their mouth made when they sipped.

“I like that the hill at Laurel Acres is cut wrong,” he said. “It’s not a good hill. It humps and then slopes like it’s tired in the middle. It doesn’t belong here. The rest of the park is so…” He gestured with his hand to indicate something like “made by a committee,” then laughed softly. “I like that it’s wrong. That makes it right.”

“Good,” they said, and their voice did something like turning a light on. “Keep that. Practice liking things that are wrong.”

He left feeling lighter and then heavy. He wanted to cry. He wanted to eat a bagel. He wanted to find the person whose phone voice had called out for Mae and tell them that everything they wanted was already inside their pockets and they just had the wrong coat on. He drove to the store and let the fluorescent lights smear everything into one substance. He counted screws. He sorted a bin of washers by diameter and found satisfaction there that he could not find in any human face. He took lunch in the back room and found a note in his lunch bag in handwriting that looked a little like his own but too neat, too careful. Good boy. Eat the apple. —M.
He looked around the break room. Dina sat at the far table, talking to someone he could not see; her hand moved in the air as if she were swatting a fly. Sonia came in and then came back out, as if she had committed and then uncommitted to something. A man in a neon vest stood by the vending machine and the machine rejected him by blinking every black light at once. Cornelius folded the note and put it in his wallet behind a picture of the hill at Laurel Acres that he’d taken one fall when it had looked particularly convincing.

He thought, briefly, to text Julian. He thought, I could say: I saw the unicycle horse on the news. He thought, I could say: I read Chapter 3. He thought, I could say: Do you like bagels with salt? He did none of these. He ate the apple. He threw the core away and then took it back out and laid it on a napkin because he couldn’t bear it face down in a circle of lettuce. The day moved like a body in pain that no one knew how to handle.

After work he drove down a side street he didn’t know he knew. The houses on that street looked like a row of people holding their breath. A woman on a porch yelled, “Mae!” and a cat stood up on its hind legs and put its paw against the screen door and said nothing. He parked and sat in his car and did the thing where you put your forehead to the steering wheel and do not cry and do not cry and then breathe and pretend you did. He went home.

The book on his pillow had a pink sticky note now that read: Sad windows are a you thing. Discuss. —J.
