He laughed and then didn’t. He went downstairs and found Julian on the floor with Tux, who had her head tipped back to stare into his eyes. They were having a conversation, clear as any other, and Cornelius had the feeling he was a third person in a room where two had already decided to be friends.

“Do you want to go to a show?” Julian asked without preamble when he walked in. “I mean later. Not tonight. There’s a place in Haddonfield, or Haddon Heights, something with an H, anyway there’s this singer—Rowan? Rowan something. They have this way of making even the stupidest line feel like a truth you can sleep on without back pain.”

Cornelius put an apple back in the fruit bowl and then took the apple back out because it had touched the lip of the bowl and he had the idea the apple and the lip did not like each other. “Sure,” he said, and it came out like he had rehearsed it. He hadn’t, but his mouth was good at pretending. “You don’t have to invite me to things because of the upcoming—” He waggled his hands. “Family.”

“I know,” Julian said, and his face settled into a seriousness that made him look older. “I want to. I’m not good at…you know.”

“You are,” Cornelius said.

“I talk too much and then not at all. I disappear at weddings.”

“Good skill,” Cornelius said, and felt his throat loosen. “I disappear at the dentist.”

“Right in the chair?”

“Poof.”

“You’re something,” Julian said. “I mean that in a way that’s not an insult.”

They leaned against opposite sides of the doorway and let the silence gather. Cornelius could hear Elaine upstairs running water, running it twice, the second time longer than was necessary. He could hear the traffic on the street, a staccato. He could hear Mr. Dwyer’s key in the lock, then not, then the sound of it dropping to the porch and a soft curse and then the key in the lock again. He could hear his name spoken in the corner of the room in a voice that had once belonged to his grandmother. He turned his head. The corner was empty but the voice had the shape of dust in it, and he wiped it off with his hand. He did this almost without thinking. He did so many things between thinking.

That night they went out for ice cream and sat in the car at the edge of the strip mall because it was raining and the tables outside were slick with a thin film that made them look like they had been glazed. Julian talked about a job that might have been offered to him and might not. Cornelius ate his chocolate slowly, letting it melt and then taking it back. A group of teenagers sprinted past and then sprinted back again in a loop like they had been wound by a key. The neon sign in the pizza place next door flickered and held. The rain came down at a slant that made it seem like the sky had started to tilt.

“Do you want to get out of here?” Julian asked, and then clarified, embarrassed, “I mean the parking lot. Not the town. Not your life.”

“Where would we go.”

“Laurel Acres,” Julian said, and laughed at himself. “We’re those people now.”

They went. They sat in the car at the top of the hill and watched the slick citizens of the park move through each other's reflections. The rain made pools in the places the hill sank. In the rearview mirror, Cornelius could see his own face. It looked better there than in the bathroom at home. He decided never to look at his face except in reflective surfaces he couldn’t control.

“There,” Julian said, pointing at a particular tree, its leaves heavy, its trunk dark. “That’s a good tree.”

“I don’t understand trees,” Cornelius said. “I mean, I get them. But I don’t understand when people say one is better than another.”

“This one knows the right words. Look at it.” Julian leaned forward and his hair stuck to his forehead. He made a small noise of frustration like a kettle just before it whistles. He turned and looked at Cornelius as if someone had told him to find a thing he would miss when he lost it.

They did not touch. The car was fully human: it made noises in its own body and suffered and grew older with them. Cornelius wanted to put his hand on the back of Julian’s hand, then imagined what that hand would feel like in the hours afterward—how the skin would carry the memory like chalk. He wanted a new alphabet for this thing. He wanted to know what percentage of himself he could spend before he was poor.

“Tell me a secret,” Julian said. It was not a dare.

“I put the apple core on a napkin,” he said.

“That’s not a secret.”

“It is to the trash.”

“Try again.”

“I don’t remember Tuesday,” Cornelius said, and then, because the car felt like the kind of room you could chat with about your failures, he added, “I went to work. I have moments from it. I know there was a piece of paper in my pocket when I took my jeans off that had a phone number for someone I don’t know and the name ‘Mae’ written in the top corner and I tore it up because I don’t like what it feels like when you keep a thing that doesn’t know how to be kept.”

Julian looked at him. He was very still. The rain rattled the roof of the car like applause. “I forget, too,” he said, finally. “But when I forget it’s because I want to. You sound like you forget like the town gets fog.”

“It’s not like a movie,” Cornelius said, and he had to say it, had to hurry. “It’s not dramatic. It’s just like you put down a glass and then you’re sure you didn’t, and then you don’t go looking for it because you’re embarrassed to have lost a glass. It’s like that, over and over. Small kindnesses you don’t do for yourself anymore.”

“Do you tell Dr. Vale?”

He smiled at the windshield. “They know. They operated on me last year and took out the part of me that remembered Tuesdays.”

Julian did not accept this joke. “Do you…are you scared?”

“I’m always scared. I think that’s the base note. It’s just that sometimes there’s harmony and I can’t tell where it’s coming from.”

“It’s okay,” Julian said. And it was a thing to say. It was something to put into the glove compartment and carry around for a while. Cornelius felt the words like a new penny he didn’t want to spend. He put his fingertips on the ridge of the glove compartment for a second, then pulled them away like it was a person’s cheek he should not have touched.

“Do you want to come tomorrow,” Julian said, “to the place with the singer? Rowan? The H towns? We’ll get lost and then unlost and then pretend we meant to do it.”

“Okay,” Cornelius said, and it fit.

When he went to bed, he found a new note. Coffee before the road? Meet me at the Wawa on 73, 5:30. I’ll be the one with the two coffees and the look of betrayal if you don’t come. —J.
He sat on the edge of the bed and held the note and felt too old for this and too young and exactly right at the same time. He put the note under the book. He undressed in the dark, as he did when he didn’t want to see the history his body had written in dabs and scrapes and small computers of pain. He lay down and slept a heavy sleep that was not a sleep but a sink.

He woke at three to the sound of someone washing dishes in his kitchen and went downstairs and found the sink empty and his hands wet.

He dried them and went back to bed. He told himself that in the morning he would be rational and put every thing in a bin and label it and see that nothing was moving when he looked away. He put the thought in a box. He labeled it with a piece of tape and wrote in his best, careful handwriting: DO NOT OPEN ALONE.

In the morning the Wawa parking lot had that washed-out bluish light that turns every car into the same car and every person into a part of your day you haven’t lived yet. He saw Julian’s yellow hoodie like a flag put out for an obscure holiday and felt his chest fill with something like the moment you get on a ride at a county fair and decide to trust the bolts. Julian was holding two coffees. He held one out. Cornelius took it and felt the heat and did not wince. He told himself it was good to hold hot things. It was practice.

“You came,” Julian said, and it was not relief so much as recognition, as if they’d been planning this meeting all their life and had nearly missed it.

“I would always come,” Cornelius said, and then he wondered why he had said that, as if he had started in a different conversation and brought the end of it here.

Behind them, someone called, “Mae?” A voice with a shape he knew. He turned. The parking lot was a shuffle of sneakers and a spill of napkins someone hadn’t caught and the dark mouth of the store and the glint of a trash can lid. He saw no Mae. He saw, for a moment, Mr. Dwyer standing by the door with the crossword folded into an origami bird. He looked again and it was not Mr. Dwyer, it was a teenager in a varsity jacket laughing into his phone.

“Ready?” Julian said, and Cornelius nodded and followed him to the car. He put his coffee in the holder that had a crack in it, a hairline that had been there since the beginning of time. He watched Julian’s hand on the gear shift. He watched the rain start again even though the weather had promised it wouldn’t. He watched the town open itself to them like a book with a fold in one page already.

On Route 73 they found a rhythm. Julian sped up and slowed down in time with the cars in a way that made Cornelius think of schools of fish. They passed the places Cornelius had gone for paper plates and batteries and the places Elaine had gone for wedding things and the place where a florist had told them it was fine to be late, it was always fine, and the place where Mr. Dwyer had shouted into his phone about grout. They passed a giant billboard advertising accident attorneys. They passed a smaller billboard advertising forgiveness. The river was on their left for a while, and then it disappeared like a friend you thought was following you in line.

“You ever think about leaving?” Julian asked.

“Only in the daytime,” Cornelius said. “At night I believe in everything.”

“That’s when it’s easiest to be fooled.”

“I live there,” Cornelius said. “It’s home.”

Julian laughed, then rubbed his eye with the heel of his hand. “Tell me something the hill told you.”

“It said I don’t have to keep any of this,” Cornelius said, and thought: I don’t know if that was the hill or me pretending to be the hill so I can do the thing I want to do and blame the landscape.

“You have to keep some of it,” Julian said. “Not all of it. Not a collection. Something that fits in your pocket.”

“I have a note,” Cornelius said, and then he did not say anymore because they arrived at a red light and a truck next to them made a noise like a flood and he was afraid that if he spoke he would drown himself. He touched the note in his pocket anyway, like a superstition, like a map.

The show was in a room that used to be a pizza place; you could smell the ghost of cheese. Rowan stood on a little platform and sang into a mic that had been dropped many times, its grill dented like a knuckle. They sang about people who put their fights in jars and stack them in the attic. They sang about a man who walked into the ocean because he thought it owed him an apology. They sang about a house with a floor that sloped so gently you had to lie down on it to understand what was happening to your body. Cornelius stood close enough to the stage to feel the air moved by Rowan’s voice and far enough that he could pretend none of the words were about him.

Julian swayed. He looked more comfortable with music than with conversation. He closed his eyes. He did not let them stay closed; he checked his corners and then closed them again. Cornelius wanted to memorize that motion and then wanted to forget it so he could be surprised again. He wanted things that were not reasonable to want.

Afterwards, they stepped into the alley to breathe and to get away from a man who had told them at least three times that he had been to LA and found it shallow. The alley smelled like garlic and damp and the hope that a cat would appear and solve your problems. Julian tipped his head back and said, “See? Back pain free.”

Cornelius felt sweat on his neck and the little cool scratch of air when a breeze found him. He said, “The song about the attic,” and Julian said, “Yeah,” and that was enough.

When he went to pay for their drinks, the woman at the counter said, “You’re Cornelius,” as if she were introducing him to someone inside himself. She had a name tag that read MAE and a small scar between her eyebrows that made her look like she spent a lot of time thinking hard about unfixable things.

“I guess,” he said.

“I like your bolts,” she said. “You do them well.”

He stared, then realized she was teasing him, except he could not find the crease of a joke on her mouth. He paid. He left a tip that made no sense for the purchase. He went outside. He said nothing to Julian about it. He put the receipt in his pocket and did not look at it later.

On the drive home, he fell asleep for one long blink and woke to Julian tapping his arm, gently, not the way Rick would have, and saying, “You know where we’re going,” and he said, “Always,” and then they were back with the hill in the dark and the house with the lemon smell and the cat who had made a bed of the stack of clean towels. They put their keys on the table in the front hall. His key made a noise. Julian’s key made a more urgent noise. He looked at the notes on the fridge. One was in Elaine’s handwriting: Eggs? Another was in a blocky print he did not immediately recognize: Cornelius—fix the light in the downstairs bathroom. I keep seeing my head in it and it’s not my head. —D.
He stood and felt, for a small pinch of time, that the house was full of people standing in the places where he had ever stood. He felt that if he turned too quickly he would collide with himself. He thought of the hill and what it had told him. He thought of the planes, and how easily they vanished when he looked away.

He went to bed. He did not turn on the lamp. He lay on his side and listened for whatever it was that would tell him he had done something irreversible. He heard nothing. He slept, and in his sleep he walked down a long hallway with the sound of a soft pencil on paper following him, and when he turned around there was no one there, just his own footprints in the wax, and then even those disappeared as if the floor had changed its mind.

He woke to a ring of damp on his pillow and the conviction that he had made a promise in his sleep. It lived in his mouth like a coin he’d been holding between his teeth, sour and shiny, unspendable. The house was awake already; it had that mid-morning industry that meant Elaine had taken the day by both sleeves and shaken it. He could hear the vacuum bumping gently into the ottoman, the ottoman offering no apology and no resistance, the vacuum retreating and gathering itself for a second attempt. He lay still long enough to watch the light in the room shift from a flat square to a trapezoid that made a neat shadow of the book on his nightstand, and he thought: sad windows look like this when the day starts misaligned. He reached for the book without looking, opened to the chapter with the paperclip rust mark, and let his eyes snag on a sentence about how glass remembers the people who look into it too often. The sentence had the taste of penny again. He closed the book and put it face-down because he didn't want the room to catch him reading about itself.

On the refrigerator there were three new notes. One was in Elaine’s round, emphatic hand: Don’t forget Mr. Dwyer’s casserole dish. One was in a thin, precise script he recognized as belonging to the bridal boutique in Marlton where Elaine had put a deposit on a dress that made her look like someone else’s best story: Fitting at 2 p.m., please no lotion. The third was blocky and a little impatient. Cornelius—fix the light in the downstairs bathroom. I keep seeing my head in it and it’s not my head. —D. He held that one between forefinger and thumb and let it lean. He knew the shape of Mr. Dwyer’s D; it was like a front step with a crack in it. He folded the note and put it in his pocket as if that would quiet it and went for the toolbox.

The downstairs bathroom had the kind of light people mistake for clarity. It was too high, too bright in one quadrant, too dim in the corners. He turned the switch and watched the bulb blink, catch, blink again—a tired eye—then hold. The mirror needed a proper bracket; someone had installed it with a faith in adhesives that bordered on religious. He stood and looked at his head the way you look at an object in a store window you might steal if you weren’t yourself. He saw the slightly wrong tilt of his ears, the hair he had tried and failed to make obey routine, the little nick on his cheek he didn’t remember earning. He tilted his head left. The man in the mirror tilted right, because mirrors are contrary. He lifted his hand and watched his hand rise up on the other side. There was a breath between the two motions, the smallest lag. It might have been in his head. It might have been in the wiring. It might have been the kind of thing some people would call a trick of the light. He leaned closer and thought: who is this, and why is he so committed to my mistakes.

The screw that held the fixture bent when he tried to coax it; he felt it protest in a whisper that went down his wrist and into his elbow. He took the fixture off anyway because he had the rhythm of removal in his hands; you had to listen for the way the threads wanted to be undone. He saw the wires, one with its cloth fray like a tired sock. He thought of the attic song and the jars. He thought, not for the first time, that the house was a person who had burned their tongue on hot soup very young and never tasted things correctly after that, and he was always trying to describe salt in a way the house could understand. He stripped the end of the wire and retaped it with a neatness that would have pleased Mr. Dwyer if Mr. Dwyer had known to be pleased by the correct application of tape.

When he put the fixture back and tested it, the light held; it made the room a little less honest. He looked one more time at the glass. The person there blinked when he did. There was no lag. For a second, relief made him silly, and he said out loud, “You’re me,” and the mirror did not argue, because no one sensible does when the point is to get through a morning. On his way out he saw Tux in the hallway, consulting the patch of sun as if it had asked to be seen. She tilted her face to him and then back to the light like someone comparing two opinions she didn’t trust.

Elaine was at the table, wedding magazines like shallow boats all around her. She had a pencil tucked behind her ear and her hair was up in a knot that had trapped a sensation from three days ago and wouldn’t let it out. “You fixed it,” she said, and he handed her Mr. Dwyer’s note as proof of request rather than achievement. “He’ll stop the melodrama now. He keeps telling me that light has a grudge.”

“He’s not wrong,” Cornelius said. He put his finger on an image of a cake that had three tiers and a habit of leaning toward the person who didn’t want it. “This one looks edible.”

“Cakes are for photographs,” Elaine said, and then laughed because she knew it sounded like sacrilege. “Thank you. And please tell me you are coming to the fitting, because if I have to listen to Rick say the words ‘meringue bodice’ while I’m in a dressing room, I will forget my own name and never get it back.”

“I’ll come,” he said, and he meant it in the way you mean you’ll show up at a place where someone loves you beyond your usefulness. He made a note on the dry-erase board by the back door in his own careful hand, Fitting 2 p.m., then added underneath in small letters, Bring patience, bring water, bring a joke for emergencies.

Julian arrived like a soft wind; the side door knew him now and opened without the alarm complaining. He carried two paper bags and the disappointed mouth of a person whose coffee had not been strong enough but who knew not to blame the coffee. His hair was damp from a shower or from rain; he shook his head once like a dog, saw the magazines, and smiled into them with affection and a little alarm. “I come bearing breakfast,” he said, and then, “I know it’s not breakfast time, but my body is on its own schedule. I have no union representation.”

“It’s onion bagels in there,” Elaine said, peering into the bag as if it might be a small theater. “Bless you and all of your employers.”

“I want to introduce a new motion,” Julian said. “Let us as a family consider the possibility of approval for the cardigan with elbow patches for Rick. It will give him something to do with all that enthusiasm.”

“He has four elbows,” Elaine murmured, tearing a bagel with a competence that made Cornelius think of weather maps. “Find the cardigan that allows for that, and I will approve it.”

Cornelius had the pleasure of watching the two of them orbit each other with practiced care. The word family pricked him; there was a sense, always, that he had entered a room where a conversation had begun ten years ago and he had to catch up by asking one compelling question. He took an onion bagel and made it a sandwich with tomato and salt he did not apologize for. Julian leaned in the doorway and said, “The singer posted the set list, by the way. They never do that. It made me feel falsely in the know.”

“The song about the jars,” Cornelius said. It came back to him, not the words, not the melody, but the sensation of jars breathing thinly as if they had been held under too long. “Did you ever put anything in a jar.”

“I once tried to put my bad temper in a jar,” Julian said. “I labeled it ‘June’ because it was worse in summer. I left it in a drawer and when I opened the drawer in February I found it had evaporated, but only from that jar. It had moved into all the other jars that were trying to be olives.”

“That’s how it works,” Elaine said. She looked between them as if she were a teacher in a class where the lesson plan was feelings but the worksheet was wedding seating arrangements. “Cornelius, I need you at the fitting to tell me when my face is lying. Julian, I need you later to help me convince Rick that white shirts come in whisper and not just in yell.”

“Ma’am,” Julian said, sketching a salute that made Tux look skeptical. “I will arrive with a selection of whispers.”

They went to the fitting and the boutique smelled like steamed fabric and an expensive complaint. While Elaine disappeared behind a curtain with a woman named Rhea who had scissors around her neck like a medical warning, Rick made little speeches to no one and everyone. Mr. Dwyer sat on a tiny couch with his legs crossed and his crossword tilt to his mouth and asked Cornelius if he thought “kind” could be a synonym for “sort,” then answered himself and noted that all words were cousins if you met them at a family reunion. Cornelius nodded and let himself be proud when he found himself saying, “Sometimes they hate each other for how alike they are.”

In the mirror opposite the little couch there was a reflection of the curtain. The curtain moved as if someone else was back there too or as if the boutique had a draft that was superior to other drafts. Every now and then he saw not the shape of the version of his mother that belonged to his ninth birthday party or his high school graduation, but a person he did not recognize who wore her bones. He decided it was the lighting. He decided it was the curtain. He decided it was the part of his brain that liked to write poems under the word “risk.” He kept deciding things until Elaine stepped out and the language of the room changed and there was nothing left to do but witness.

She did not look like someone else’s best story. She looked like herself, which was a story. She looked like the person who had held his shirt in the dryer on the morning of picture day and told it, Be kind. She looked like the person who had once put a sprig of mint in a glass and made him feel like they were rich. He breathed out. He did not need to say anything because his face had the thing she wanted in it and she saw it. Rick said something about officiants as if the officiant were the weather. Mr. Dwyer stood up without realizing it and then sat back down as if standing had been an impulsive marriage proposal. Julian put his knuckles in his mouth for a second and then took them out and said, “You’ll need stronger shoes,” and Elaine said, “Oh, I know,” and they laughed like the only two people on a bench.

Afterward they went for coffee because Elaine believed in balancing luxury with ritual. The coffee place had the warmth of a place where the milk steamer once had a personality and then went to college. The woman behind the counter had a name tag that read MAE and a sweater with a hole in the shoulder that had been repaired with yarn of the wrong color. She took their order without writing anything down and said, “Cornelius,” with the tone of someone who is reminding you of a debt and a birthday simultaneously. He did his best not to flinch, because you could not live in this town and flinch at your name; it would wear you to a nub. He was about to say something neutral and ordinary when she added, “You left your change last time,” and handed him a quarter with a smear on its face that looked like the continent that would always show up first when he tried to make pancakes of states.

He turned the quarter over. He had not bought anything here the last time; he had never been here in this particular room, not since they moved it from its old location on the corner by the laundromat with the missing O in its sign. He looked up at her and she smiled. It was a good smile if you liked not being able to tell exactly what the person wanted you to do next. He put the quarter in his pocket with Mr. Dwyer’s note as if the two might have things to say to each other in the dark. Julian was watching him with that patient interest he had when he wanted to be a witness but not a detective. Elaine was talking to the barista about the bouquet in a photograph behind the register and whether it had been heavy.

By the time they got home, Rick had to change and go to a meeting about a meeting. He left in the way he always left, with a promise he would be back soon and a confusion about which set of keys he needed for his car, because his keys were essentially a small orchestra and each had an ego. Mr. Dwyer stayed long enough to retrieve his casserole dish and to say that the light in the bathroom felt like it had forgiven him. He left a new note on the fridge without telling anyone, which Cornelius found later: If this house were a person, I’d tell her to stop sighing when she sits down. —D. He put his palm on the fridge door and felt it hum its own reasons.

He went upstairs with the book and decided to read Chapter 3 through, properly, without skipping or charming himself with single lines. The author wrote as if they had an ear pressed to a certain artery of the county and could tell you which way the blood was going and which corners had trouble and where a building’s ankle would give if you pushed. Some houses wear faces they found in other neighborhoods, the first sentence said again, and this time he imagined their house with a borrowed expression the way you hold a friend’s phone and it makes your hand look strange. There was a section about windows that had given up: not broken, not even cracked, but resigned. When a window goes tired, the author said, it admits a different sort of weather. He thought of the downstairs bathroom. He thought of the mirror knowing someone who needed it more. He thought of his bedroom window, the trapezoid morning, and the way he had placed the book face-down to save the room from knowing too much about itself.

Julian knocked and then didn’t wait because that is what you do when you decide the person is less likely to say yes if you make them pronounce it. “We should go to the hill,” he said. “It smells like rain but they haven’t told it it’s raining yet.”

“You always want to go the second before a thing starts,” Cornelius said, and he said it fondly because the fondness felt like the little handle on a drawer you don’t always open. He put the book down and stood and felt every place his socks held his feet. “All right.”

The hill had elected to be magnanimous about the weather. It had made puddles in advance, as if this were now part of its service. The planes were out but not many; they looked preoccupied, as if they had just come from a fight two towns over and were telling themselves a story in order to land. The grass had a slick it wore like a nervous bowtie. They found their usual slice of ground and sat in the way they were learning to sit together—adjacent, at an angle that allowed for an exit and pretended it didn’t.

“There’s a word for the thing when you think you see somebody you know in a crowd,” Julian said. “Not déjà vu. Not that. The other thing. It’s about faces and how the mind cheats.”

“Apophenia,” Cornelius said, and then immediately doubted himself because the word came up wearing a coat that might have belonged to something else. “Or that might be patterns. It might be the wrong coat.”

“I saw Mr. Dwyer outside the Wawa last night,” Julian said. “Except it wasn’t him. I was going to go over and remind him not to hang wet towels on the rack he put in, but then the man turned into someone the age I am when he turned his head.”

“I did that too,” Cornelius said, because the trick of sharing is not to weigh it down. “I saw him in a jacket,” and he gestured, which was the same as saying, You’re not alone in the mis-seeing. “Mae was at the coffee place.”

“The one with the unicycle horse guy in line sometimes,” Julian said, and this was how they spoke: as if the nouns had agreed among themselves to be part of a set. He looked at the sky and it looked back like a person who thinks you are about to say something and isn’t sure they want to hear it. “We could look for her.”

Cornelius made a face and then smoothed it down. “I don’t know who she is, in the proper nouns way,” he said. “She keeps being the corner of rooms.”

“Like the cat,” Julian said, and Tux would have appreciated that if she had been there to see herself analogized.

They didn’t find Mae on the hill; they found a man with a broken kite and a father with a dot of ketchup on his cheek and a teenage girl sitting on the ground like she had been told, conclusively, that she was the problem and was practicing her counterargument in the grass. They watched a woman run past with such concentration that the air around her seemed to have been organized by appointment. They watched a flight of geese correct themselves the way a sentence gets corrected on a second pass. They did not talk much. The sound of a train arrived as a rumor and then became an event behind the trees. When the first drop of rain hit his wrist, Cornelius looked at it like a receipt he was not sure he needed to keep.

At home there was a new voice in the vents. He knew because it said his name the way his ninth-grade math teacher had said it when the question of whether he had the right number of parentheses had become a moral issue. He stood in the hallway and listened to the vent as if it were an uncle. He did not call for anyone because experience had taught him that inviting witnesses made the magic go home and sometimes he preferred to watch it stand unashamed in his kitchen and then leave of its own volition. The voice said, “Corn,” which was what his room said, and then it said, “Done,” very distinctly, and he had the dark, distantly funny sense of someone ticking a box.

He went upstairs and checked each window by putting his forehead briefly against the glass as if it were a person with a fever. The glass had the same temperature as his thoughts, which was no help. In his nightstand there was a scrap of paper he did not remember putting there. It had the neat version of his handwriting on it and read: Tuesday groceries: screws (brass), green beans, bread, forgetfulness. Eat apple. —M. He sat on his bed with the scrap and let it sit in his lap like a small polite animal. He thought of the apple core on the napkin, the mercy he had shown a piece of trash, and felt something complicated move under his sternum like a suitcase going down a flight of stairs very quietly.

When he showed the note to Dr. Vale the next day, they held it with two fingers as if it were evidence and a tissue. “You wrote this,” they said, not as a question but as an observation left on his coffee table for later. “But you also found it. How does that feel.”

“Like there are two of me,” he said. “One of them is late. One leaves me fruit.”

“You like the one who leaves fruit,” they said, and it was as soothing as being told you liked something you already knew you liked. “M.”

“I don’t know who that is when it isn’t me,” he said. “Mae is real. She has a sweater with a hole. She knows my name. But then the notes. And then Mr. Dwyer’s note about the head that isn’t his head. And the bathroom light being a person who uses the wrong pronouns for us on purpose.”

“You’re not wrong,” they said. They had their leg thrown over their knee and their sock was a color that made him think of pediatric waiting rooms. “What happens if M is just a part of you that had to sign himself because you needed the signature.”

“That would be relieving,” he said. He pressed his thumb into the chair notch that belonged to him. “It would be relieving to be an ordinary split.”

“And if M isn’t,” they said, not invested in the answer and entirely invested in watching him find it.

“Then I don’t want to know yet,” he said. “Sometimes the knowing gets there before the wanting is ready to be a place.”

“Practice that sentence,” they murmured, simply pleased by it. “Keep your windows halfway. You can let the weather in without being responsible for the thunder.”

When he left their office the plant in the waiting room had been replaced with not a plant but a photograph of a plant. It sat in the same pot, printed in glossy, as if someone had told it to hold its pose for longer than plants are built to pose. A new sticky note on the frame said: Succulent in memoriam. Please refrain from watering. —D.V. He smiled and then stopped smiling and put his fingers behind his back as if water might leap from them without his consent.

He drove to work and the store hummed and the bolts weighed wrong and he took pleasure in being able to tell. He rearranged a display of hammers so their heads looked a little less like threats. He made a small ceremony of shaking the rug in the entry, because the rug had a habit of trapping gravel that made all the carts complain. At lunch there was another note in his bag in the neat handwriting. The bag had a sandwich he did not remember making and a cookie he would have chosen if he had been the person who had made it. Good. Practice letting someone like you. —M. He folded the note and put it with the others and then took it out again and read it once more as if it were going to change while he watched. He thought about showing it to Julian and then did not because he did not know how to explain the generosity without also explaining the fear that came with it, and fear makes everything tacky if you’re not careful.

At night he and Julian lay on the living room floor with Tux between them like a referee who believed in none of them. They were not touching but they were in the same dimension. The television was on but muted; a man in a suit said important things with his eyebrows and no one felt threatened. The window in the living room had one blind slat that had started to warp; it made the light from the street into a little wave across the ceiling. “I keep thinking about the song with the floor that sloped,” Julian said. “It’s the worst kind of slow catastrophe, where you want to believe the whole time that you are deciding to lie down.”

“The house we rented when I was seven had a floor like that,” Cornelius said. “If you put your pencil down on the desk it would roll and you could learn what you had done wrong by whether the pencil came back. I had a teacher who put tape under one leg of each chair to make things pretend to be right. It worked like makeup. It didn’t work like gospel.”

Julian turned his head and looked at him the way you look at an animal in your yard you want to invite in but you’ve watched enough nature shows to know about wildness. “We can get the floor in this room leveled,” he said. “Rick would approve of a project he can talk about at parties.”

“I don’t know,” Cornelius said. “I think I like the slant. It makes you very aware of what you want. You have to decide to sit.”

“Practice deciding,” Julian said. “Practice liking the wrong hill.” He reached out and let his fingers touch the carpet an inch from Cornelius’s hand as if demonstrating a concept. “Practice letting someone like you,” he added, and then looked at the ceiling too quickly, as if the confession had been a moth.

Cornelius breathed. He could feel the seam in the carpet with the tip of his finger. It was like the line between two days, and how you do not know when one becomes the other until you go to wash your face and realize the mirror is tired of showing you the old one. The house made a sound in its bones like a yes. From the kitchen came the sister sound of plates settling. From somewhere under the floor, or over it, or in the vent that ran past the hall where the half-room said his name, he heard the small, unimportant sound of someone putting a glass down carefully so it would not startle anyone, and then he heard nothing, which lately was his favorite sound in the world.

He woke in the middle of the next night to a smell of citrus. It was not the lemon cleaner; it was an orange that had been cut open in another room. He went downstairs and found half an orange on the counter with its own absence of bite marks, the way a fruit looks when it has been performed at rather than eaten. There was a napkin tucked under it with a single word written in the neat hand: Later. He stood with his hand on the counter and the counter’s cool pushing against the meat of his palm and thought about what it means to be told to wait by a thing you want. The refrigerator hummed as if in sympathy. The clock on the stove said a nonsense time and then corrected itself, and then said the nonsense time again, as if it were practicing its panic.

The next day at work he caught sight of a woman in the aisle with the flashlights whose hair was the color of tea you make for someone you love and then forget to bring them. He had the certain uncertain sense of having known that hair before. She turned and her face arranged itself into someone who had stood behind him once in a line that moved like a train in fog. She looked at him with real curiosity and then at the flashlights as if they could help, and he did what he could: he found the batteries that would last longer than anyone promised and showed her how to open the little plastic hinge without swearing. When she left she said, “Thank you, Cornelius,” and he wanted to ask for her name so that he could put it somewhere and see if it left a note for him later, but he let the moment leave with a proper posture.

There were two new sticky notes on his pillow when he got home. One was from Julian, unsigned except for the way the J tailed off twice and then the tail decided to be its own letter in a separate alphabet: The window on the stairs looks like it wants to say something. If you catch it, tell it I’m listening. The other was from M, or from himself pretending to be M, or from the part of him that had decided that giving himself permission required paperwork: You don’t have to hold the hot thing long enough to prove you can. Just touch and tell. —M. He lay on his bed and held both notes and had the disconcerting feeling that he had missed the point once by holding a thing too long. He put the notes under the book because the book liked to keep company.

The show in Haddonfield had loosened a small knot in him he had tied himself when he was twenty and believed if he did not tighten it, the world would accelerate without warning and fling him. He went with Julian to the grocery store and did not leave when the fluorescent light decided to be a personality, because Julian was there and because he had the note in his pocket that said Later and it had to choose a later and this was one. He picked a bag of green beans for no reason and then put it back because the green beans had been picked out of the bag by other hands and he didn’t like the public intimacy of that. He bought milk and bread and a lemon. He bought a pack of screws because he couldn’t not when he saw them poorly placed. He carried the bag to the car and felt like he had balanced something he could not name.

At the house, the stairs window had condensed on the interior, little half-circles of moisture like sentences in a language he had not agreed to learn. He touched the glass with the back of his hand, just a grazing, and it pulsed under his skin the way music does when you stand too close to a subwoofer at a party you did not want to attend. He did not know what it wanted to say. He did know that the house had a way of telling him things once and then leaving it to him to remember, and lately remembering felt like trying to catch a moth without hurting it. He went downstairs and found Julian on the couch with Tux draped over his lap like a garment. “It’s saying you should clean it,” Julian said, without looking up. “It’s a practical poet.”

“I’ll get the vinegar,” Cornelius said. He said it in a voice that made the glass and the cat and the man on the couch into something you could call joyful without feeling like you had lied.

He cleaned the window and the vinegar smell made him think of nights his mother had spent in kitchens that weren’t theirs, making them smell like home by force. He watched the way the cloth moved across the glass, the way the streaks agreed to organize themselves under the pressure of a hand. He talked to the window, quietly, the way you talk to a thing you want to reassure. He told it that they were making decisions, that they were not always good at it and sometimes they counted planes instead of houses, but they would get there, or here, wherever here was. He waited for the word that would come through from the other side, the way voices sometimes came through, and when none did he accepted the quiet as the answer. He could do that. He could learn to accept quiet and call it a sentence.

Later, in the kitchen with a towel over his shoulder like an apology, he cut the orange in halves again and put the quarters on a plate. He wrote M on a napkin and put the napkin under the plate and felt a ridiculous sense of theater that did not embarrass him, which was growth. He left the plate on the table and went to bed and woke in the night to the sound of someone finding the plate in the dark without knocking anything else over, and the next morning the napkin was gone. He waited for fear. It didn’t come. He found, instead, a note on the back of a receipt for onions that did not match anything they had bought. The note said: Good. Braver than yesterday. Let that count. —M. He put the receipt with its onion price in his wallet behind the photograph of the hill and felt himself add the number for bravery to some ledger he hadn’t realized he had been keeping since he was the age when you first understand that wishing doesn’t make your parents love each other more but you keep doing it because you’re superstitious about despair.

They went to the hill again, because that was what they did now when the day felt like a room with too many people in it. The planes obliged them with their obedience. The geese pretended to be governors. The grass pretended to be something it wasn’t and did a convincing job. They sat and counted, because counting is a kind of spell. Julian talked about a job interview he had postponed, about the way he was practicing answers in the mirror without wanting to stare into anyone’s head that wasn’t his. Cornelius talked about bolts and the way the weight had shifted since the new supplier, about the possibility of telling his manager in a way that didn’t sound like an accusation. He could feel the box in his head he had labeled DO NOT OPEN ALONE; he could feel that something in it had changed shape, and he understood suddenly that what you put into a box doesn’t stop moving just because you shut the lid. He leaned back on his elbows and let the unimportant pain in his wrists tell him he was alive.

“Tell me the truth,” Julian said, his voice the kind you use when you want to invite a person to step onto a piece of ice with you. “Did the hill tell you anything today.”

“It told me not to collect people the way I collect screws,” Cornelius said. “It told me to keep only what fits in my pocket and doesn’t cut the lining. It told me to learn the difference between heavy and good.”

“And Mae,” Julian said, not because he wanted to know but because the pattern demanded the name.

“She was at the coffee place,” Cornelius said. “She gave me a quarter I didn’t deserve.”

“People do that,” Julian said. “They give you change for a bill you haven’t handed them yet.”

“Do you ever think we’re all versions of the same person in different lights,” Cornelius asked, and the question left his mouth before he could give it a belt and shoes and a haircut. “Like the way a house wears faces from other neighborhoods. Maybe we’re just neighborhoods wearing each other’s faces until we forget to give them back.”

Julian looked at him like a joke that had landed and then found it was a bird. “If that’s true,” he said, “then I hope I get your eyebrows. They’re decisive. They know what they want without being cruel about it.”

“You can borrow,” Cornelius said. “But I want them back by Thursday.”

“Deal,” Julian said, and he held out his hand in a theater of handshakes that neither of them went to because sometimes the metaphor was enough, and sometimes touching was a thing you saved like a small currency.

That night the house breathed differently. Rick came home with a speech and no audience and gave it anyway to the cat, who looked unimpressed and warmed. Elaine put the magazines away as if performing a ritual for a god of paper and then sat at the table and hummed without memory of ever humming. Mr. Dwyer called to ask if the light was behaving and left a message in which he apologized to no one for doubting his own eyes. The downstairs bathroom light held. The mirror did its job and only its job. The note on the fridge that said If this house were a person had acquired a line under it, underlined by no one like an agreement. Cornelius stood at the bottom of the stairs with his hand on the banister which had been worn by three other families and knew the exact weight of their rings, and he let the house have its say, and he had his, which was to go to bed with the book open to the rusted paperclip mark and to dream of a window that opened not onto the yard but onto a room where someone who signed his name with a neat hand was sitting with a cup of tea and a pencil and a willingness to wait.

Chapter 5

The first thing he did when he woke from the window dream was put the book on the floor, because it had been too close to his head and he could feel his thoughts smudged where it had rested. The second thing he did was reach for a pen he kept in the drawer with socks that had given up on being pairs. He sat cross-legged on the bed with his hair doing the thing that made him look like he had been listening to static too closely, and he wrote on the back of a grocery list for a week that was not this one. He wrote, Hello, which felt formal and unnecessary, and then he wrote, If you are me, thank you for the apple and the nerve. If you are not me, please leave the sink alone when I am sleeping. Underneath that, he added, What do you want. He folded the paper into a small, square politeness and slid it under his pillow the way people in stories hide teeth for fairies. He did not expect anything; it is easiest to wait when you have removed expectation from the room like a bucket you keep tripping over.

Downstairs the day had put on a dry shirt and decided to be responsible. Julian sat at the table with a bowl of cereal that had given up being crisp, reading a job listing on his phone and making a face like the job had told a joke he was not in on. Elaine slid toast into the toaster with more ceremony than the action required and was telling the butter, out loud, to remember it was butter and not a soap. Tux had her paws on the chair rung, the picture of practice. “There’s a flea market on Saturday,” Julian said without looking up. “Columbus. They have a guy who sells old doorknobs like they’re records. I thought you might want to…you know.”

“I always want a thing that used to be a thing,” Cornelius said, and he said it in a voice that told Julian he’d already said yes. He poured tea and put sugar in it in the increments that made doctors sigh and wait for a better moment to bring it up. The idea of the flea market arrived in his head with the smell of soft pretzels and wet cardboard and the particular sadness of a bin of remotes whose televisions had gone on without them. He saw, in advance, a table with little drawers, one missing a pull, and the careful handwriting of a person who had labeled each drawer “Assorted.”

Elaine said she’d make coffee for them to take and then forgot she had promised and then remembered at the exact moment she opened the fridge for something else, and she laughed at herself and made the coffee with great seriousness. “You boys need hats,” she said. “Even when it is pretending not to be summer, the parking lot is a pan.”

“Dad says hats ruin a man’s hairline,” Julian said, deadpan, and Elaine rolled her eyes to a place where her mother would have been waiting with a spoon to say that hairline ruin started in the womb with unpreparedness. It was a house built of small lines like that, and if you kept them in your pockets you always had something to give back to a person who expected nothing and was delighted by the thought of change.

They left on Saturday before the town had fully decided which errands it would commit to. The Wawa lot was a composition in gray, and then there was Julian’s hoodie like a declaration, and then there was the coffee and the way Cornelius liked to hold heat briefly and then let it go to prove nothing to anyone. The highway gathered them up and put them down in a field arranged into lanes by vendors who believed in their own ability to create order out of old toys and kitchen implements. The sky had a flatness to it that suited rummaging. The men who shouted at you to come see a miracle were selling knives or tape or the idea that if a thing cuts through a shoe, it must therefore be good.

What he liked best about the market was the ache of specificity. You could turn your head and find a collection of snow globes that had come from one woman’s life and each had been shaken when a certain song came on in a certain December. You could find a crate of old house numbers, each one a way of saying Here we are to a stranger who had meant to go next door. He walked past a table with a tangle of chargers and watched a man in a neon cap pick one up as if it might forgive him his sins. He watched a child pick up a cracked crystal doorknob and declare it a gemstone and then be corrected by a parent who liked truth like a hobby. He stopped at a spread of brass hinges and felt the heft of them in his palm the way you hold a history and see if it intends to keep talking.

The woman behind the table with the doorknobs and sash weights had hair the color of tea you forget and then sip anyway. Her sweater had a hole mended with a darker yarn that made the hole honest instead of repaired. When she looked up at him, she made a small sound of recognition that was softer than a “Hi” and more specific. Her name tag read MAE in the tidy capitals of someone who had considered lowercase and declined. She lifted a sash weight as if she were showing him the heart of someone who had been a good house.

“These were made when gravity had a code of ethics,” she said. “Feel that.”

He did, and it was the kind of heavy that tells you it intends to be loyal. The weight sat in his hand like a long single thought. “They put velvet in shoes now to make them feel like this,” he said, and Mae smiled as if the sentence reminded her of someone she had been fond of in a life with more socks in it.

“You carry yourself like someone who has learned to tell the difference,” she said. “Between heavy and bad.”

“I am practicing,” he said, and the table made the polite sound of a surface that would prefer you not put your coffee down on it. Julian circled and found a metal tin with a picture of a ship on it and said, “This would make a good place for secrets,” and then realized he had said it out loud and colored as if he had shared a baby photo.

“I keep quarters from nowhere,” Mae said. “I put them in a medicine bottle and pretend I’ve cured something. Some days I spend them and it’s like telling a joke to a cashier and you both know it’s not very good but you are saving the day anyway.”

“My name is Cornelius,” he said, because the rhythm demanded the equation of strangers, and her eyebrows did a small, delighted lift at being given the name she already had known. “You gave me a quarter.”

“I returned it,” she said, and her tone held that fine edge between tease and insistence. “Debt is a door, not a weight. Don’t carry it, use it.”

He bought a sash weight not because he knew what he would do with it but because it made the heaviest sense. He bought a handful of glass knobs, none of them matched, to make a future drawer happier. Mae wrapped them in the brown paper you can only find at markets like this, paper that used to be part of a person’s map. She handed him the bag and then, like a friend passing a note under a desk, tucked a small folded thing into his palm. He did not look because he understood the religion of delayed revelation. He thanked her. He did not tell her that sometimes his apartment keys made a noise at the same time as voices in vents. She probably already knew in the way people like Mae know what kind of light has a grudge.

They walked. Julian carried the tin and the weight as if he were demonstrating a metaphor to a class that might not deserve it. He talked about the job again, and this time there were specifics; there would be a man named Reggie who had worked there forever and liked to pronounce acronyms as if they were his grandchildren, and a woman named Shaila who had once trained to be a florist and now maintained the database like a bouquet she was determined would not wilt. Cornelius listened and said the right encouraging things without making them into a spell. He bought a bag of kettle corn that turned his fingers into a small grease festival. He considered a set of chisels because they were honest and sharp and then left them because the day was already holding many corners.

Back at the car he opened the note from Mae. It was not his handwriting, but it had a family resemblance, the way cousins stand in the same way when they’re thinking. The paper had been torn from a book of receipts; the back had onions listed at a price that felt aspirational. The note read, Do not be so good at leaving yourself breadcrumbs that you forget you can stay in the wood. —M. He put it in his wallet with the others and felt, as always, the small compression of fear followed immediately by the relief of having something to hold that wasn’t a worry. He did not show Julian. He wanted to, but the note had hands of its own and wanted to be held by one person at a time.

When they got home, Rick was rearranging the hall closet like a man practicing for a TED Talk about the misuse of space. He had a shoebox full of batteries he’d bought in bulk because he liked any word that promised abundance. He said, “Look at this, can you believe how they wasted the top shelf,” and Elaine said, without looking up from a list of song choices the DJ had sent, “It’s where I keep the winter.” Mr. Dwyer arrived with a bag of oranges like a punchline and said a thing about scurvy that made Tux leave the room out of principle. The ordinary accumulation of a day took courage to stand inside of, and Cornelius felt heroic just moving his shoes out of the doorway and not hitting anyone with the sash weight when it knocked his shin through no fault of its own.

He carried the weight upstairs and put it in the corner of his room as if that corner had been cheating on gravity and needed to be reminded of its responsibilities. The book on the floor looked up at him without apology. He touched the pillow and felt the note beneath it like a thought. He left it. The experiment was to wait. He could do that. He could practice not jostling the universe and calling it patience.

At dinner, Elaine asked if anyone had strong feelings about aisle runners. Rick advocated for something that looked like the jersey of a team he had invented and loved. Mr. Dwyer advocated for clean shoes. Julian advocated for walking like you meant it, which made Elaine kiss him on the head in the manner of a person appreciating a sentence and its speaker equally. Cornelius advocated for the absence of petals, because petals on floors look like regret if the lighting is wrong. They ate salad that had fallen into its bowl very willingly and a dish with chickpeas that had changed their name at least three times on their way to being served. The candles were lit because it was a day. The house gathered itself into the cool of evening and did its little shiftings and small operas. The downstairs bathroom light held without blinking and someone said aloud the sort of “thank you” you send into the part of the world that doesn’t require thank-yous to continue.

He slept the thinly satisfied sleep of a person who has not cried but has thought about it and considers that a kind of participation. He woke at three the way he does. The pillow had a new weight. He turned on his side and retrieved the note underneath like a magician pulling a ribbon out of his own mouth. The same neat hand had written, I want to be allowed to want without being the only one who wants. Leave the door on the chain sometimes. I can reach through. —M. He read it twice and then once more to make sure the letters weren’t moving when he looked away. He put the note with the others, then did a thing he had not thought he would do: he wrote back on the back of a dry cleaning receipt from a suit he had worn once to a graduation that had not entirely belonged to him. He wrote, The chain is on. Try me. He slid it into the gap between the door and its frame where the chain lives, and he went back to bed. He did not sleep. He lay and felt his heart perform planning meetings.

In the morning, the receipt was gone. In its place was nothing at all, which was either rude or the point. The chain sat with its own pride. He made tea and did not tell the tea what it needed to be this time. He told Julian instead that he had found a thing for their future drawer, and he told Elaine that the sash weight would make a good argument against certain drafts, and he told Rick that the batteries had best not be near the stove because the house did not like combative objects huddling. He told no one about the note and its disappearance and the way his name had started to sound in his head like the last light of evening on the kitchen table when everyone gets up but the table remains, gathering the day as if it had been invited.

He kept his appointment with Dr. Vale because those were the kinds of appointments you keep if you want to build anything that doesn’t fall over when the washing machine thinks too hard about suds. The waiting room had the photograph of a plant in the old plant’s pot, and a new photograph of a plant that had presumably died elsewhere, as if to keep the first one company, as if the room were a small gallery of failures that had decided to be art. He touched neither frame out of respect for what you are not meant to correct. Dr. Vale wore a sweater that made him think of schools and halls with waxed floors. Their hair did what hair does when its owner has stopped trying to influence it and has moved on to other ambitions.

He told them about the market and the weight and Mae’s note about woods and crumbs. He told them about the chain. He did not tell them about the half-grief that followed the word “Try me” being taken seriously by a person who might be him and might not. Dr. Vale listened the way good translators listen when the speaker believes they are speaking the only true language. “Boundaries,” they said, not as an order but as a diagnosis for something that had survived. “You did that without writing ‘No trespass’ on your forehead. How does it feel.”

“It feels like I put a sign on a window and the window didn’t mind,” he said. “I expected to be punished for deciding anything.”

“And the notes,” they said. “Do you want less of them.”

He looked at the fake plant pretending to do its job without chlorophyll. He looked at the actual M note folded perfectly in his pocket, making its little right angles of insistence. “No,” he said. “I want permission to want them without labeling it a symptom.”

Dr. Vale did the smile they do when they have recognized a good use of their own vocabulary in the wild. “You can ask for that. Start with yourself. Then try your kitchen. It’s often more forgiving than your head.”

They talked about Julian then, and how it was easier to be kind in a moving car. They talked about the wedding and how a public ritual can make private quiet easier to place in the house without apologizing to the furniture. They did not talk about fear like a monster under the bed; they talked about fear like a small dog that barks because the world makes doors slam. When he left, the photograph of the plant looked relieved that he had not tried to water it with his worry.

On the day of Julian’s interview, the house put its hand on the small of his back in the gentle pressure of everything going well if you pretend the going is optional. Julian wore a shirt that had decided to be brave and a jacket that thought it could make him look like he could afford to hear no and keep breathing easily. He stood in the doorway and made the motion of leaving three times, then stopped and looked at Cornelius and said, “Tell me a thing I can put in my pocket.”

“Your hands smell like oranges,” Cornelius said, and then quickly added, “In that good way when you open a peel and it makes the room remember that winter ends. You can take that. It’s a fact. It is not dependent on their mood.”

Julian nodded the way you nod to a doctor who is recommending a treatment that has fewer side effects than panic. He took a breath that made his ribs remember they had been made for something besides protecting frightened things. Cornelius reached for a scrap of paper and wrote, quietly self-mocking, QC-MAN APPROVES, then drew a little tape measure with a cape. He folded it and handed it over. Julian tucked it into his wallet as if it were a photograph of childhood that needed a new home.

The hour after Julian left was an hour made of slow objects. The clock on the stove huffed. Tux stared at a spot on the wall until the wall apologized and offered to be more interesting next time. Elaine went to look at flowers alone because sometimes she needed to practice making decisions that no one protested, and also because she liked the smell of green in the cold compartments where flowers wait. Rick called twice, once to ask if the red tie made him look like a judge of something and once to ask where he had put his lucky pen that was just a pen that had once signed a thing that had not later been regretted. Mr. Dwyer knocked and then remembered he had a key and then knocked again and got his own timing wrong. He walked in and stood in the kitchen and said, “What is the word for when the house is saying something only you can hear and you will seem unwell if you ask someone else if they hear it too.”

“Tuesday,” Cornelius said, and Mr. Dwyer made the face of a person who had been offered a cookie you weren’t sure you had earned.

They drank tea and Mr. Dwyer told a story about a co-worker who had taken up beekeeping and now had opinions about the quiet of rooms he used not to care about. The notes on the fridge had tried to be helpful and had ended up sounding like the menu of a very specific restaurant. There was one from Elaine: Bring pins. There was one in Julian’s hand, quick and leaning: If I die in a lobby, tell them I loved the fish. There was one from M, because of course there was; Cornelius found it tucked behind a magnet shaped like a corn cob that someone’s aunt had considered whimsical. It said, You asked. I want to stand in the room with you when you decide and not press my thumb on the scale. —M.

He took the note upstairs and sat on his bed and folded and unfolded it until it resembled an idea that had been lived in. He put it under the book’s cover, between Chapter 3 and the chapter about stairs that forget which step is the last and love to trick you. He touched the chain on the door without looking at it and was surprised to find it warm. He realized he had fallen in love with how he began trusting things and was not yet ready to tell the things about it.

Julian came home with the air of someone who had been asked to judge a parade of hats and told he wore his own head well. He stood in the doorway and did a small dance that was entirely in the elbows and said, “I was not terrible,” and then let himself lean against the wall in exactly the way he did when his body did not know yet where to put a relief. He took his wallet out of his pocket and opened it to the little cape and said, “He was there,” and Cornelius said, “He has very strong opinions about adhesive labels,” and then they stood in the kitchen and allowed themselves to be pleased without saying a single sentence about deserving it.

The wedding date scooted closer in the friendly, aggressive way dates have in the middle of the calendar. Elaine tried on shoes that cost like a choice and walked in them in the hall with the determination of a woman being honest about pain. Rick practiced a speech in the mirror that began with a joke about how he had once thought marriage was like joining a bowling league and then realized he had to learn his partner’s release and footwork and temperament and have a good cry in the parking lot when the pins knocked themselves down in his heart. Mr. Dwyer made a list of people to sit near people who would make them less awful. Cornelius took his sash weight downstairs and hung it temporarily in the hall to explain to Rick the concept; Rick pretended to understand and then later said to Julian, “What is it,” and Julian said, “A very nice rock,” and Rick felt satisfied.

The house began to make a new sound at night, not a yes and not a no, a longer word he could not hear all of. It began, the sound, near the vent, and moved along the seams of walls as if looking for the right place to end its sentence. He woke at two and lay with his palms flat against the sheets to see if the quiet was in his hands or the room. He heard the half-room say his name in its slow syllable and then, much later, he heard it say, Wait, as if you were saying it to a dog you intended to treat. He said, “All right,” out loud, so the house would not feel it had to be theatrical to get his attention.

He saw Mae twice more before he decided that choosing not to ask a person if they know you is a kind of ethics and maybe also a kind of fear. Once she was in the store for batteries and once she was standing at the end of the aisle that held gutter hooks for lights, considering the physics of cheer. Both times she greeted him with his name as if he had volunteered it, and both times she left without buying the thing that had called her into the place; some people step into rooms to make sure they still exist, and then they go. The second time, as she turned, he caught sight of a scar on her wrist in the exact place where his watch had once raised a rash, and he had the thought that human bodies conspire across distances to make the same mistakes for the same reasons and then meet in aisles to prove it. He put his hand to the screws because that was his scripture.

One afternoon, Rick came home with a carton of eggs that turned out all to be brown, which Elaine preferred because the brown ones looked more like eggs had looked in her childhood when chickens had been closer to them; he made a triumphal noise as if he had returned with treasure from the city. He put the carton in the fridge and something in the way he closed the door reminded the fridge of a story, because later when Cornelius went to get a lemon, he found a sticky note on the inside of the door that read, You do not need permission to be here. This is not a store. —M. The note had been stuck behind the butter. It had gotten cold on its way to him. He warmed it in his hands and thought for an unworthy second about turning the note into a refrigerator magnet, and then he told himself you didn’t turn permission into a product.

That night, Julian and Cornelius lay on the living room floor again because the carpet had ideas about therapy and the ceiling had accepted its role as confessional. Tux took up residence on the couch back in the way of cats who want to watch without committing to any one person’s gravity. They watched a movie without the sound and improved it with their own voices, and at some point, because sometimes you do touch a person in your life even if you have sworn not to for a month to see who you are without that, Julian’s hand drifted and landed on the back of Cornelius’s wrist. It was a touch like specification. It was not long. It was not romantic in the way songs make paints peel. It was exactly enough to make the nervous system say, I see. He did not jerk away or laugh. He did not narrate it. He did not later mention it when he wrote a note to himself in his head about how he wanted to go very slowly because he did not trust the part of him that liked to sprint toward people and throw his wallet and his personality at their lawn.

On a wet morning when the planes had decided to take the long, careful route, he met Dr. Vale at a diner that had survived three separate renovations and had the kind of walls you could forgive for their complaints. They had not planned to meet; he had texted and they had said, “I am near eggs,” and he had said, “I approve,” and then he had gone. They sat in a booth with a rip that had been mended with tape in the same way some people apologize too loudly and you are embarrassed on the behalf of your own discomfort. He told them about the chain and the kitchen and the note on the butter, and they told him about a dream they had had about finishing shoes in which everyone wore their plan on their feet and the hard part was agreeing to go the same amount of distance as the person you loved.

“Collecting,” they said, stirring coffee with the concentration of someone trying to make a point perform. “You collect screws because they are useful, and because they are alike enough to comfort you and different enough to keep you from feeling stuck in Mormon wallpaper. You collect notes because you are teaching yourself a way to be told. Let yourself have. Then ask yourself which things have souls that want to be held and which things want a drawer and a label and to be ignored until they are needed. There is no moral superiority in being needed.”

He played with the sugar packet and did not rip it, because ripping is a choice some mornings and not a release. He thought about a box he had in his head and about the label on it he had written in his careful, school handwriting when he was so young he could still smell paste as a fact. He considered the idea that boxes could have windows and chains and you could be the guard and the guest. He did not say any of this; he told them instead that he had bought a sash weight because gravity needed reminding, and they nodded as if he had brought them flowers.

The day of the final fitting arrived like a guest who you feared would be early and was instead exactly on time. Elaine’s dress hung on the door and made the light in the room do what light does when fabric invites it to behave. The boutique had unlocked a patience for them that had been hidden behind plastic garment bags. Rhea the seamstress had her small sticks of chalk lined up like a family. “Shoes,” Rhea said, and Elaine produced them with the glee of a person committing to a conspiracy their feet might regret. There was a small, predictable chaos. There were people in small chairs pretending they were not crying at a person standing in front of a mirror trying to balance the story of herself with the cost of hemline. There was a bouquet being gently scolded by a friend for its lack of structural integrity. Rick did his best to be both there and not there, which is a man’s greatest test in rooms where lace is deciding everyone’s posture. Julian was good at handing the right pins and not stepping on the train and finding the humor that did not soil the moment. Cornelius stood and watched the way the mirror arranged the room and the way the room let the mirror lie a little for their benefit, and he felt nothing dramatic; he felt a plain true thing in his chest like he had put down a heavy bag finally and remembered he had hands.

He went outside for air and found Mae on the bench by the tree that had selected itself in Julian’s taxonomy as a good tree. She had a paper bag of pretzels and offered him one exactly the way a friend would in a lunchroom you had accidentally walked into twice. He took it and did not make a thing of the salt stuck to his lip. She said, “I like the window in there. It tells the truth about what light does to a person.”

“It’s a good window,” he said. He thought about asking her if she had left the note on the butter, and then thought about the violence of trying to force a person to match a ghost with your own handwriting. He let the thought wave and go. “You come to weddings,” he said, a sentence that was not an accusation and sounded like one to ears trained to hear the world as trouble. “I mean, to places where people pick what to wear in case it rains and doesn’t.”

“I like fabric stores,” she said. “I like rooms where people collaborate on a future and say ‘Let me think,’ and you can watch them do it. I like alterations. I like the noise of pins in a dish. And I went to buy thread,” she added, producing two spools the exact color of sky an hour after the day ends from a pocket in her sweater that had been mended and remended until it had the texture of a decision you had to make ten times before it stuck. “You looked like a person who would need someone to hand them something if they put their hands in their pockets too long.”

“Thank you,” he said, because that was the word you say when a person has bought thread and memory without reminding you of the price. “Do you know that the plants at my doctor’s office have become photographs.”

“I knew they would,” she said, with the confidence of someone who has seen many things decide to be images. “It is a mercy for both parties. The plant was not fit for the daily rain of certain kinds of sentences. The photograph can take it.”

“Do you leave notes on people’s butter,” he asked, finally, and she laughed, a sound like a lens cap popping.

“I am not your mother,” she said, not unkindly. “I am not your angel. I am not your memory with neat borders. I am a person with a sweater that does not give up. I am a person who knows you know how to fix a light without bullying it, and I like that. That is all.”

He nodded. He could feel the place in his chest where disappointment had tried to prepare a bed. He did not lie down in it. He went back inside and became, again, a person inside a particular day, and that is a job that deserves to be listed when people ask, What do you do.

The night before the wedding there was chicken that had been roasted in a pan older than any of them. There was a salad in a bowl the color of a friendly argument. There were napkins folded with the kind of care that becomes a joke later and then an heirloom. There was a silence after they ate that was not uncomfortable. Rick put his hands on the table and felt the way a different life would have made him a person who drummed on surfaces when he needed attention, and he declined that life in favor of this one, where he could say, “Let me tell you about a day I didn’t know anything and it was fine,” and be believed. Elaine sat in her chair and looked at the men she would call her men and thought about shoes and sorrow and how you arrange them so both behave. Mr. Dwyer washed the chicken pan with tenderness and a minimum of self-congratulation. The light in the downstairs bathroom held. The vent said nothing or said everything and he had stopped needing to decide which it was.

He went to bed and put his hand on the book and thought about the chain and the door and how there is a sweetness in being able to hear a person’s hand on the other side, not knocking, just being. He woke in the night to no smell at all, which was unusual and a gift. He lay and listened to the house do its breathing, the same as his mother had done in the room down the hall, the same as he had done as a child when he swore he could hear his own blood move and had named it a train to make it less lonely. In the morning, there was a single note in the kitchen stuck to the salt cellar with a magnet shaped like the state of Delaware. It read, Keep your windows at half-mast today. There will be weather. I trust you. —M. He laughed a little in his throat because he had expected a list; the note had offered him a sentence and a vote.

The wedding day was a series of small competitions. The weather tried to be both and instead landed on gentleness with a show-off cloud. The vows tried to be original in a town where people had been promising and failing and promising again since sidewalks were chalk. Elaine tried not to cry and then cried anyway and forgave herself with the efficiency of a woman who does not have time to be embarrassed. Rick tried to keep the speech under seven minutes and went to nine, but only one person looked at a watch and that person was Mr. Dwyer because he was timing the moment to tell a story that needed a precise entry point. The photograph that would end up on a mantle had three versions: the one where Cornelius looked like he had accepted something, the one where Julian looked like he had been told a good joke and had tucked it under his tongue to keep, and the one where Tux, who had been smuggled into one group shot as a dare, looked like she owned the house and its social calendar.

There was dancing. Cornelius did his small version of dancing, which is to say he let the music move the area from his elbows to his shoulders and did not attempt anything below the knee that might have suggested he had ideas. Julian did the kind of dancing you do when you have spent enough time in rooms where people forget they have bodies and then remember with relief.
